reviews.review: Beautiful Basilica. This is a must see. While it is a hike to get there, it is worth the trip. From the massive 5-level bell tower to the impressive Mosaic facade to the 150 column quadriportico courtyard with the statue of St. Paul - it is humbling and impressive. The interior art and architecture are magnificent. And, while there were tour groups going through, it was not crowded. Waiting a while, between groups, we were able to view the tomb area basically by ourselves. One of the best churches in Rome.

Now crowds, beautiful organ music, impressive architecture. This is the place to go if you want to enjoy beauty and silence . (aside from the odd clown who doesn't seem to get that he is not in a bar.) it is the perfect escape from the tourist centre of rome. Take the time for the monastery, sit in the garden, walk the cloister. Very unusual marble columns. Great vibe.

must visit, never crowded. La Basilica di San Paolo is not properly in the city centre but just outside, I live in Rome and I always suggest to visit it as lots of tourists don't know it. A good thing is that it's never crowded and there is a subway stop 200 meters far.

Not so Hidden Gem. This is one of four must see churches in Rome along with St Peter's. This church is dedicated to St Paul and is one of the largest churches in the world. It dates back to 400 AD. Be sure to get the audio guide or listen to the recordings near the entrance to the church. The art and architecture are amazing.

Humbling beauty. Magnificent Basilica! We had a calamity of errors getting there that included a 5 mile hike. But, once we arrived, it was completely worth it. Next to St. Peter's this is the most impressive and feeling inducing basilica I've ever been to. It is massive yet calming. The paintings, statues, the courtyard and St. Paul's tomb are all inspiring. I recommend this for anyone visiting Rome. Absolutely worth visiting. Dress conservatively and act appropriately.

Huge. The Abbazia is a magnificent place, huge in dimensions and spiritually rewarding for believers as much as atheists. Its high ceilings and its enormous columns make the visitor feel as small as it gets. Occasional singing makes the atmosphere even more special than it would without. Also, it is free to visit. What else would it need?

Magnificent basilica with history !!. We loved the basilica, beautiful with history of San Paul. It worth the drive there. Don't miss the archeological museum with the cloister. Altar with mosaic similar to the famous one in Ravenna.

A stunning site of spiritual significance. If I want some peace and quiet in a place steeped in the Christian tradition then St Paul's withoiut the Walls, especially on a sunny day when the afternoon and evening sun shines on its gleaning facade, is the place to go. A short bus ride on the 23 or on the metro from Termini, you can spend an hour or so here in tranquillity compared with the hustle and bustle of St. Peter's. Don't miss the cloisters and the excavations. Or the excellent cafe and bookshop. The tomb of St. Paul is a special place in a very special building.
Wonderful Church. Really magnificent, it's really huge, definitely not to be missed, worth visiting, wonderful structure
It has a unique charm!. I think this is totally a must when visiting Rome! it has a peaceful environment that you don't find in the most commonly visited churches in Rome.

Beautiful. Had wanted to visit "St. Paul Outside the Walls" on my previous visit, but didn't have time. Was glad I made time on this trip. Very impressive. Not nearly as busy or crowded as the other Papal Basilicas in Rome. Get the self-guided audio tour- it is a big help. This basilica is not near most of the usual tourist destinations in Rome, but is about a block from a metro station, and is worth a visit.
In great condition and a lot of history. Great history and wonderful arquitecture, is a most in Rome together with St,Mary the major. St. Paul is burried here.

Easy to find one of the 4 famous churches of Rome.. This building is stunning along with its statues and bold colorful interior decoration. Not to be missed are the collection of Popes from the first to the current, a painting of each is on the interior wall with only a few spaces left for the Popes of the future. Easy to get to just use the B line metro the stop is a 5 minute walk on level ground.
A very important church. If you come in Italy, you have to visit it. Gardens are beautiful and the church is gorgeous. You can see all the pictures of all the Popes inside it.

not to be missed. Beautiful basilica; resting place of St. Paul. It's easy to get here by metro, and then a 5 minute walk from the station. For the nearly two decades now the visitors can actually view the edge of the stone coffin in which supposedly St. Paul was reburied during the reign of Constantine the Great. There are even libation holes drilled into its lid and inscription attributed to the 4 century.
Go there!. So many people miss this. The ceiling, the precious stone altars and stone (yes, stone) windows are beautiful. Its very close to Basilica San Paolo Metro too.
St. Paul Outside the Wall. The grounds were beautiful. Religious aspect of the visit was unmatched and not nearly as crowded as St Peters in the Vatican. Tomb of St. Paul was moving.
ride the elevator. this is a very beautiful with lots of steps. visit the museum on the side. it is 242 steps but there is a elevator after that that goes to the top and you can see all of Rome.
Beautiful. Worth seeing. Empty while I was there....when the rest of Rome was packed. Please note that this church has been rebuilt in the past 150 years....so it's relatively new by any standard.
Umbria holiday. Gigantic building, very big and quiet so place to pray and contemplate. Not many tourists about. You will see burial site of Soul/Paul the apostle:-)

Incredible. I have to admit, I love Roman Catholic churches, despite not being religious. This one brought tears to my eyes - it's an incredible space and really easy to get to. It's on the main blue line - just 1,50€ each way if you don't get a travelcard and so worth the trip out of the city centre.

Beautiful Basilica. Since is it outside the walls, The St. Paul Basilica, offers a quieter place to pray compared to the other three major Basilicas. As equally majestic to St. Peter's, John Lateran and Maria Maggiore, the basilica of St. Paul allows its visitors, especially Catholic pilgrims to walk around and pray without the hassle of having too much noise from the number of visitors. Pilgrims and visitors alike could see the burial site of St. Paul the apostle under the main altar of the basilica.During summertime, it's ideal to go here during the late morning and early afternoons, especially if one doesn't want to collapse under the scorching heat of the sun.

Amazing church and a remarkable historical site. Beautiful church with very well-preserved areas dating back to the first and second century. Off the beaten path from most tourist sites, but well worth the trip, especially if you're also visiting St. John Lateran which is a short walk away. There is no charge to enter the church itself, but there is a fee to enter the underground historical sites that include the first century home and the churches that were built in later centuries on the same site. This is a particularly interesting site if you've studied early Roman history or early church history. If you pay to enter the historical sites, you will receive a brochure of the site but it would be best to hire a guide or study about the church and its history a little before you arrive, especially the cult of Mithras. For anyone interested in early Roman history or church history, this is a site that shouldn't be missed.

Very Beautiful. We found this place by accident. Did not expect to see such an amazing church. It is free to visit and there is a lot to see. There are big cloth that women can use it to cover their shoulders and knees. It is an amazing building with outstanding painting and statues. Metro station is just 5 mins walk. Must see
A different Basilica. San Paolo is a different Basilica from the other three that are in Rome, the main ones.The style and the silence, something you can appreciate for sure.

A beautiful church. St. Paul outside the Walls is a large complex. It takes a while to tour the church. Crowds here are smaller than at the Vatican. There is a small cafe (nice), good restroom facilities, and a bookstore.

A really astounding church. We haven't recognized how time passed by while walking through this church. We easily spent an hour inside without getting bored. It's a beautiful church.You can buy access to the church yard which holds a small exhibition and grants you access to some excarvations. But even without it, the church is really nice.

A must see, slightly off the beaten path. Built over the site of St Paulus grave this basilika is amazing. It's hughe and so beautiful - and nowhere near as many visitors as in the church of St Peter!

St. Paul's Sarcophagus and a Lovely Afternoon. The basilica is beautiful, well kept, and security was fairly tight. An easy metro ride and short walk. It is incredible that the Roman Church has managed to retain this artefact and display it in such an attractive setting. The high ceilings, the artwork, the chapels all make for a lovely and thought inspiring afternoon. Allow some time for some contemplation. The basilica will not be very interesting for young children or people who don't have an interest in religion or St. Paul, everyone else will be highly touched by the sarcophagus, the artwork and the various chapels.

Massive and beautiful. One of the four papal basilica's in Rome, St. Paul's Outside the Walls is an easy metro ride away. It's massive - only St. Peter's beats it in terms of size, but it's also truly beautiful with some gorgeous art work. Unique to St. Paul's are the small round paintings of every pope from St. Peter up to Pope Francis. This is a cool visual reminder of both apostolic succession (the reality that every bishop in the Catholic Church can trace his position back to one of the apostles) and of the ancient lineage of the Church. Very much worth the trip!

St Paul's Outside The Walls . Lovely peaceful basilica with impressive interior and a relaxing exterior. Fascinating even for a non catholic to see the portraits of all the popes (which a little boy visiting at the same time as us found rather spooky). Can be reached by public transport and is free to the public. Should tens and knees should be covered or entry will be refused.

One of the nice churches in Rome. One of the impressive church buildings, with great works of art.what to see: the door of bronze with inlaid silver showing events from the life of Paul and peter.Look for the 12th century candelabra and the baldechino, (embroidered fabric of silk,and gold over an important person) dated 1285. See the chapel of relics housing the supposed chains of Paul and many other relics.

Impressive Bascilica. Huge and very ornate Bascilica - with amazing art works, including painting of each Pope with current given a spotlight. very impressive painted apse ceiling depicting Christ and the apostles, Massive paschal candle holder and reliques of St Paul

Just say go!. This is one of my favorites! The beautiful courtyard was made to allow the pilgrims to prepare for the mass before entering the church. The pictures of the papal succession and frescoes were the highlights inside. This basilica was peaceful and uncrowded on our visit and a definite must see.

One of my favorite places in Rome. An amazing basilica one of the four main papal basilicas and the second largest church in Rome. Portraits of all of the popes can be found along the ceiling on either side of the interior of the church. St Paul resting place can be viewed before the main altar. A must see!

Calming, spiritual. Beautiful basilica only three stops on the metro from the Colosseum. Peaceful full of history, free entry, mass almost every hour. For us a more positive experience than the Vatican. ladies if you forget your cardigans or shawl, you can get a blue disposable one at the entrance but please leave a small donation.

Amazing Experience. With the exception of St Peters this has to be the most impressive of the Papal Basilicas. It is breathtaking and the mosaics are stunning in their sacred depictions. The space and the feeling of openness not only allows freedom of movement but an experience of freedom- the freedom to communicate openly with our creator.
Beautiful!. i like this place!It is very beautiful with all flours, antiques and pleasures!Rome is amazing with all places that he have!!!

Not to be missed. This is a must see. Its a bit out of the way, but oh so worth it. It is just beautiful. I agree with other reviews, it should be on the 'must see' list. Do not leave Rome without seeing this stunning Basilica.

Complete your Jubilee pilgrimage. The main purpose of my trip was to have a nice vacation week with my wife away from work, kids, and everything. However, as we are both somewhat religious, part of our trip ended up being a pilgrimage as we were lucky to be in Rome on an exceptional Jubilee year announced by Pope Francis. This church concluded our pilgrimage to the four main churches in Rome were the Holy doors are opened on a Jubilee year. Who knows the other three? :) Entrance is free and easy.

So many churches in Rome, but this one worth a visit. The traditional burial place of St. Paul, this church has it all: it's not crowded, has some beautiful art, and feels worshipful and serene. We enjoyed our visit here.
Don't miss it. So beautiful!! Really love the little garden in front. I was there at about 4.30pm, surprisingly not crowded. Those ceiling is just Beautiful!

A remarkable place. One of the most remarkable Papal Basilicas, along with Saint Peter's. It was founded over the tomb of Saint Paul and was expanded and restored many times until 19th century. It is worth to see the bronze doors and walk along the Basilica to admire the relics, pillars, the tabernacle, the tomb of Saint Paul (and pray a little if you have faith on this saint), wonderful ceiling and the astonishing apse mosaic (my neck ached 'cause I stared it too long). Getting there is not difficult at all, you can take Metro (Line B) by Termini Station and walk a few minutes when you get to Basilica San Paolo Station.Be sure to view another interesting thing: the portraits of all Popes above the columns, with a special light on the portrait of Pope Francis.

fantastic roof. fantastic roof. The church was lighter than expected. I was surprised by the strict security controls also here. The church is easy to get to via the metro station San Basilica (that Google maps does not always show!).
The altar is Lapis and malachite!. I was bowled over by the beauty and the calm of St Paul outside the walls. It is a vacation for your mind and soul. Calm, beautiful, peaceful.

Basilica and Abbazia di San Paolo Fuori Le Mura. It stands on the site that tradition identifies as the tomb of the apostle Paul (about 3 km from the site - called " Tre Fontane " (3 fountains) - where he suffered martyrdom and was beheaded); the saint's tomb is located under the main altar. The body of the church is preceded by a beautiful courtyard and at the center of the courtyard is a statue of St. Paul, made ​​of Carrara marble.The facade above the colonnade is decorated with mosaics painted between 1854 and 1874 which were inspired as much as possible to the original of the tenth century. The mosaic is divided into three bands. In the lower part, on a gold background, are the four prophets of the Old Testament: Isaiah, Daniel, Jeremiah and Ezekiel. Above them, the 'Agnus Dei' on the mountain of paradise from which flow the four rivers symbolizing the Gospels, which are drinking twelve lambs, symbolizing the apostles. In the gable triangle, there is depicted Christ Blessing place in the middle of St. Paul and St. Peter. A favourite Basilica!

Don't miss it!. Take the time to visit this spectacular Basilica. It is unlike any other church I have visited. I loved studying the complete Papal mosaics from Peter to Pope Francis. Don't miss the tomb of St. Paul under the altar and the smaller chapels behind it. It is well staffed with friendly people and has a lovely gift shop and yummy cafe. The columned courtyard was lovely and well kept.

Best of the best in all - in all senses. Being the second largest of all churches in Rome and Vatican (after St.Peter's), it is perceived even larger, as there usually are incomparably fewer people inside.It was built on the place of St.Paul's tomb and in 2006 it was announced that a white marble sarcophagus probably containing the remains of St.Paul had been found there.Beautiful mosaics from early 13th century, special atmosphere - it's the experience not to be missed.The church's store has some beautiful exhibits for sale as well as books, cosmetics, etc.By the way, this is another place where one can mail a postcard bearing Vatican stamp.All in all - do visit the place, it's really a must.

Peaceful oasis. We came here on a pilgrimage on a day we saw all three major basilicas (we saw St Peter's another day). We started with Mass in a side chapel and then had time to explore. This is less crowded than the other basilicas but shares their ornate decoration, while, somehow, feeling simpler. Of particular beauty are the alabaster windows and the cloister and courtyard. We all wished we had longer.

Peace and tranquility. After a trip around the Vatican and Sistine Chapel where everyone has a selfie stick and is gurning for the camera, this place is lovely. Hardly any people and all respectful of the religious significance of the building. Pictures of every pope to date are around the walls ( there were lots of them). All in all very impressive.

Off the beaten track - very much worth the effort to visit. I love coming here at it opens early in the morning or just before closing. The vast cavernous nave feels like a forest with marble tree-trunks looming out of the penumbra. Space, quiet, art - they combine to allow awe and contemplation to take hold. This church was rebuilt after a devastating fire - they did such a good job. Beautiful. Maybe then travel to EUR to find the hard-to-find church where St Paul was supposedly beheaded!

Huge jaw-dropping Basilica. This takes some work to get to, but the Basilica was beautiful! St. Pau's remains are supposedly buried underneath this church. It's free entry, but there is a security tent to go through. It is beautiful to look at and walk through.

Most beautiful Basilica I've ever seen. . Stopped here to have a look and I was amazed. It's so stunning and breathtaking.. Inside it isn't filled with tourists and it's peaceful.. Honestly my favourite monument in Rome.. Worth a visit

Very worthwhile, but takes an effort to see. There is no shortage of churches in Rome - it is worth the effort to see some of them, while others fall into another category where you may lump them all together.The major, or papal, basilicas (basilici?) fall into another level altogether. Partially because they are important to the religion, but also because you can get there a bit more easily via transit, or even on a tour.San Paolo outside the walls is an excellent place to visit simply because it's not in the middle of things - as such as it's a sort of oasis that can provide a break from everything else, except that it can be a little challenge to get to. While you are there enjoy your time, since it's all too brief.

Not very visited with holy door. I particularlt like this Basilica because it is not visited by many tourists. Possibly because it is not in the town centre. Beautiful architecture and mosaics. It has a Holy Door

Tomb of St. Paul. If you are a fan of the saint, this is a major basilica about 200 meters from the metro station. Unfortunately, you'll have to walk all the way around the metro station to get through security, so in the end you'll walk a good half kilometer. It's a lovely basilica, a bit low key, possibly a bit overhyped or insufficiently explicated, which leaves one with the sense that it ultimately lacks the staggering amount of art one associates with other Roman churches. It is far less visited than other basilicas in the city, but it's an architectural landmark. Recommended, but not necessarily on your first trip to Rome, unless you want to see all the major basilicas or you have a special devotion to St. Paul. Pro tip: the Benedictine monks of the abbey next door make candies and chocolates, which you can buy in the store.

Still a place of prayer and quietness and not a museum.. Well worth the journey out of the centre of Rome to visit this place of devotion. A church very well cared for by the Benedictine Monks who are wecloming and delighted to meet you.

less visited. This place is amazing, the sheer size of it & it's Free, The art work & marble is unbelievable. This is also a working chapel so if you're lucky enough to see one of the services. There is one small part you have to pay for & that's for the cloister area. Well worth a visit.

Our highlight of our trip to Rome.. We visited this place purely based on trip advisor reviews. How happy we are that we followed the advice of previous reviewers and visited this amazing basilica. The queue was only about five minutes long (and that was probably only because we happened to arrive at the time that an event was on). It isn’t hard to get there, and taking a trip on the metro allows you to experience another part of Rome that many tourists don’t experience. The ticket machines have a Union Jack on them to indicate English, so it is all pretty easy. It is only 6 stops (I think) from Termini and from the metro station it is less than a five minute walk. You can see the basilica from the station so you’ll know where to walk.The basilica is staggeringly beautiful. Of course all the churches in Rome are beautiful but this one is in another league. I have to admit I haven’t been to St Peter’s or the Vatican City so I cant compare it, however it is just awesome (in the full sense of the word) all the same. We were very fortunate to visit at a time when something was going on – hundreds of people with black capes and someone who we think was a cardinal was there. There was also Gregorian chanting/singing which was, with the excellent acoustics, even for a non-believer – a moving experience. Obviously this wouldn’t always be happening, we just got lucky.It was my highlight of our trip to Rome.

ESSENTIAL!. This is the grave of the Apostle Paul. There is high security here so don't take too much in. You go through scanners. Also cars get broken into in the area so watch out. Given that, this is a real memory and confirmation that Christianity is real, true and the Holy Word of God stands the test of time!

My Favourite. not as well visited as the other three Basilicas, St Pauls is equally spectacular. Its emptiness gives an insight into the sheer scale of all four churches. It contains the relics of St Paul and can be busy on feast days or church holidays. the mosaics of the Popes along the tops of the inside walls are fascinating. Take the metro to the local station which is a short walk away.

Peaceful. The Benedictine abbey that is located next to the Basilica di San Pietro Fuori Le Mura is a monastery complex about two kilometers outside of the Aurelian walls (hence its name). It was built on a site of the tomb of Apostle Paul and its origins goes way back before the 6th century when the first document, mentioning the monastic presence here, was found.
Don't take a back pack!. Great basilica but only one entrance if you take any sort of bag and that means a detour if you arrive at the wrong entrance - including if you just want to attend a service.

Must see church. Even thought it is not located in the center of Rome, it should be on the "to see" places for sure. Beautiful church with great pillars going through the main nave. Highly recommended.

The resting place of an Apostle. This is an amazing, and huge Basilica a short metro ride from the main sites in central Rome. St Pauls tomb is located in the vast building, and walking through the various parts of the Basilica is pretty awe inspiring just in sheer scale. From the massive doors to the ornamental garden squares to the small antechambers and especially the huge main spaces, there is lots to see. Security is tight, including airport style metal detectors but go midweek and its not very busy.

Beautiful and peaceful place. This church I visited after Vatican, and I finde it most heavenly, most spiritual and more peaceful than all the others. Basilica is the burial place of the St. Paul the Apostle, founded by Emperor Constantine in the 4th century. It has totally different atmospheree, realy divine.

A Papal Church that is a Treasure. This is a place most people skip but it is a beautiful church and easy to get to on the Metro. Another important Papal church and St. Paul is buried here. It has an interesting history so read up on it. The Mosaics are incredible and there are portraits of all the Popes.

amazing church. you have to visit this church. it's very easy to visit. you have to take the subway line b San Paolo stop. between the church and the subway there is also a mcdonalds and some bar and restaurant to refresh. in the church area you have a nice museum to visit. it's a unesco site from 1980.
Don't skip this one. We almost didn't visit this one as it's pretty far from the city center. Don't make that mistake! Might be the best church in Rome.
Heavenly!. While in Rome, one must visit as many basilicas as they can see. They are all work of arts. This basilica is the farthest from the center of Rome but worth seeing.
tourist day. it's wonderful place. it's incredible architectonic structure inside the church. If you stand up your eyes, you can see the pictures of the Popes, all popes about catholic history .

Stunning!. This church is absolutely stunning, so very beautiful and spiritual. It's not very busy at all and the size and beauty of it are breathtaking. Very easy to get to: get the B line metro from Termini and get off at San Paolo stop, the church is 150 metres from there.
Wonderful. Really an unexpected place. A very big church, with the square aside and a little park at the entrance. Must visit.

Well worth the effort of a visit. Although this church is a little outside the centre of Rome it is well worth the effort. It has beautiful cloisters and the cameos of all the Popes on the wall are interesting too.

Almost better than the Vatican!. Took the metro to this attraction and arrived very quickly. It is a spectacular church with beautiful mosaics and stained glass windows. There is also the crypt of St.Paul along with his imprisonment chain. You can also go into the archeological museum of the attraction and admire the remains of the original church that used to stand before it burnt down. I personally believe that this church is superior when compared to the Vatican.

Holy Door Pilgrimage Site. This was the last of the four major basilicas visited while in Rome and it stands out as my favorite. More peaceful and calm than the others. Beautiful and spiritual. One of the best gift shops.

La Basilica. One of the eldest Basilica of Rome. It s a huge place, very important during the past and really impressive. Must to see it!!! even if i am not christian this is really a peaceful place for praying.

Spectacular structure -- go when the colonnade is open. Saint Paul Outside the Walls is spectacular historically and structurally. Seeing it should help you gain some appreciation for what St. Peter's may have looked like befor the current building was built. Also, you can learn a good deal of early church history and about early church architecture, just by reviewing a good guide book. I recommend going when the colonnade is open (it appears to have more limited hours then the rest of the church). The colonnade is spectacular from an aesthetic standpoint.
WOW!!!!!. It's pretty far from the Center of Rome, but it's a NO MISS!! You enjoy everything in this Chapel, is like a Lake on a Desert, I can describe this place, you must go.

A Must-See. This is one of my favorite churches in Rome. Since it is located outside the center, it is less crowded than the other sights. The building itself is just wonderful, particularly the little garden in the entrance.
Outstanding!!. This basilica is absolutely beautiful. Inside and out. I was surprised to find out it was free to enter, fantastic way to spend an afternoon

Somewhat obscure but worth the visit. Basilica Papale San Paolo fuori le Mura (Saint Paul's outside the Walls) is a great stop off the train on the way to or back from Ostia Antica. Get off at the "Basilica S. Paolo" stop. Personally I find the architecture superior to the Vatican and it's far less crowded. The tranquil palm-tree courtyard is a great space to take a break or a slow saunter. If you are a fan of architecture, this is a real gem.
Very nice. I didn{t spend to much time here but strolling past is a nice scenic walk. beautiful gardens out front and if youre a dan of architecture you will love this
Pleasantly suprised. This is heaven on earth, was suprised to find this as i was just touring that day, just sit and take everything in, most picturest place ive been too

SO BIG. This church is flat out beautiful. You won't believe the size of this place. I was.completely overwhelmed by what this Brasilia contains. A little out of the way but the Metro will take you there. Do not miss this. The cloister is more than worth the admission price a very peaceful place.
after the vatican it is a must see. it is a very big and lovely church you can get lost inside, what fascinated me was the portraits of all the popes it is a must see when visiting rome.

Stunning! Breathtaking!. This is my absolutely favourite church / cathedral in the whole wide wold! Must see!!!It's a majestic piece of art and history slightly outside of the core centre of Rome, so off the "beaten tourist track"
Incredible. We went there by change and I said to myself, do they need to come and visit the basilica by coaches? It was worth the trip and visit, an incredible Basilica, wonderful.

Must visit. Not as visited as some other famous churches of Rome, for me this is a special place! Huge rooms and marvelous mosaics. Can't miss it especially if you go to Rome from April to October and it is a sunny day: take a sandwich with you and eat it in the nice park outside the church!

Magnificent scenery. I was here with my dad in December and it was really really beautiful to see this church in real life but not the photos. It's not only the architecture but also the scenery with lots of trees inside the yard and kind of a large park (not really but similar) outside where you can have a walk in the afternoon. The church does not stay in the centre of the city but definitely worth a visit. I do recommend tourists to check out this beautiful church

One of Rome's 4 Major Basilicas. For sure this is the 2nd largest of the Major Basilicas (San Pietro or St. Peters being the largest) --- and for sure it is the farthest away from the center. It will take you roughly 40 min travel time from St. Peters, but I would say this is certainly worth the visit if you have time.

A jewel of amazing beauty.. This is without doubt my favourite site in Rome. There are so many beautiful spots it is hard to pick a favourite but after five trips to Rome this is one of the few places I ensure that I return to.The stunning grounds, orante ceilings and frescos, and the sheer tranquility of this Basilica never fail to move me.The gardens and historic displays from the former site are out to the rear and are very interesting.The underground display is also well worth a visit and is a welcome addition to this attraction.Do not be put off when walking toward the Basilica, it does look very plain from the outside until you get around to the front and are greeted to the sight of lush lawns, palm trees, the beautiful statue of St Paul and the amazing facia.Also, if you are a bit of a wanderer like me, it is not that far to stroll East across to the Appia Antica, about 2kms away.
Great church to see. Even if you are not religious is it a great building to see. We were first group of tourists there so you could see it empty it was impressive for sure:)

Major Papal Basilica. This is one of four Papal major basilicas situated in Rome. It is situated in Italian territory but is owned by the Vatican.There are several highlights the most important being the tomb of St Paul in the crypt below the main altar.Other highlights are the cloister ( large, beautiful , elegant and very well maintained for which a ticket is required ) , portraits of all the Popes in a frieze above the columns, the sacristy , the enormous nave and the tabernacle, the main door. the apse mosaic, etc.The overall effect is one of grandeur and greatness . This is a very imposing basilica and its connection with St Paul makes it a special place.It is easy to reach via Metro San Paolo on the blue line -- six stops from Termini.

A Beauty Outside The Walls!. This large Papal Basilica was erected over the tomb of St. Paul but had to be rebuilt after a devastating fire in 1823 but reopened in 1840. It's the second largest church measuring132m long, 65m wide and 30m high and is one of Rome's four churches owned by the Vatican. It's located near the Basilica S. Paolo metro station (Line B) and 7km from downtown.The façade has an impressive Neo-Classical portico that was built between1890-1928 with 150 columns, multi-color marble sides and a massive statue of St Paul in the center. The graceful cloister of the old monastery on the side was built between 1220-41 and survived the fire.The spacious interior has one nave with 40 columns of Baveno granite with white Carrara marble, four aisles and a gold coffered ceiling with the Papal coat of arms. The 5th C. mosaics of the triumphal arch and the baldacchino from 1285 are all that remain from the fire and particularly interesting to view. The striking apse mosaic from 1220 depicts Christ flanked by the Apostles Peter, Paul, Andrew and Luke. The windows seem to be stained glass but are actually translucent alabaster. The tomb of St. Paul is situated below the main altar and protected with a metal gate.
Beautiful. Went as part of a full day Vatican tour as this church is considered part of the Vatican even though it is not located inside Vatican city.

A visit to St Paul's grave. After a pleasant lunch at the nearby English Seminary, we were taken to this splendid Church. So much less busy than St Peter's, so more peaceful and leisurely. This is the church to see when in Rome. One of the four Major Basilicas of Rome. A fascinating, important Church.. St. Paul's is a fair way out of town but easy enough by public transport and worth the effort. The building is fascinating for several reasons.The tomb of St. Paul is here, for one.The top of the walls also have images of each and every Pope. Legend has it (total rubbish, but interesting) that the world will come to an end when the walls at St. Paul's run out of space to put new Popes!Also fascinating is the artwork over the main alter depicting Christ with Saints Peter and Paul. Usually, Peter is on Christ's right hand side (the more important side!) but since this is Paul's basilica, they are reversed. Highly unusual in Christian art.

Well worth a visit. Despite being out of the centre of Rome, the Basilica of St Paul Outside the Walls is definitely worth the small effort it takes to jump on the Metro B line...the station is even named after the church.It had a beautiful entryway with symmetrical gardens and a massive statue of St Paul holding a sword. The doors are relatively new, being commissioned in 2008 for the 2000th anniversary of Paul's birth, and contain scenes from four major scenes in his life. The interior is immense. We felt like we had the place to ourselves. It seemed very uncluttered after being in many cathedrals in the UK & France. Humbling to visit and pray beside the tomb of St. Paul. After all the churches begin to look alike, St. Paul's basilica is refreshing and a bit unique. Though still similar to other designs in Roman basilicas and churches, St. Paul's is spacious--in fact humongous--inside with many side altars and vignettes. Near the entrance to the church on the right as you enter, there is an encased scale model of the basilica worth studying to show the enormity of the building. The statue of St. Paul in the courtyard is pretty fantastic. The Benedictine sisters maintain the church so there is some dedication to St. Scholastica and to St. Benedict. Portraits of all the pontiffs line one of the rows near the ceiling with only six portrait spots left after Francis. The sunken crypt shows a corner of the tomb of St. Paul where visitors and pilgrims can pray and pay respects. Think this is where St. Paul was martyred (beheaded actually) for the faith. The paintings on the walls are wonderful scenes of the faith, easy to understand and not too overwhelming. The ceiling throughout is breathtaking. Good gift shop and cafeteria, too. Dress code enforced. The church can be seen in an hour or less, but the trip to and from adds to the length of time. The ambitious and fit pilgrims will have no problem walking there and back, but plan accordingly if you opt for this.

An oasis. A beautiful church. The outside is marvellous. It is very grand and peaceful inside. So glad to have visited.

wonderful statues. Make sure to visit the square as part of a walking return from the Vatican. The square is very interesting with a wonderful fountain. The church is deceptively large with very rich interior and amazing carvings.

The main entrance is like a park... a time capsule from Rome's grandeur. Personally, I think it's a must see... and I'm not catholic.
Abbazia di sao paolo. Must to go when you visit Rome!after colloseum and vatikan city its the most beautiful monument in the city!

Magnificant!. We got off the train back from Antica Ostia at this Church. We were just stunned when we entered this massive church. Architecturally this church mirrors the design of a late Roman Bascilica. If you want to experience something of what the Bascillicas of Ostia or the Roman Forum may have been like visit here! We then walked to the Montemartini Museum and on to Pyramid and Porta san Paolo.
Beautiful. Very exciting architecture, and easy to get to. The ceilings are so beautiful. the atmosphere was exciting!

Magnificent!. We caught the low cost Metro here without problems and as we walked to St Paul's beyond the Gates we observed the "non city" life. I was a bit stunned that no one stood up for the nuns travelling on the Metro.Cheap souvenirs, even cheap shoes are sold along the sidewalk in the "burbs". When we entered the impressive St Paul's, I (a Catholic) was astounded that there was no charge as we Catholics "always charge".It is a huge place that seems to go for miles. There are separate little chapels - some closed to the public - but so much to see. Make sure you look up and see the portraits of all of the Popes - so many throughout the ages. It is a beautiful, spiritual church. One where you can feel serenity and peace (as I did in Fatima) that was somehow lacking in the hustle and bustle of the Vatican. Just in the last few years, next to the huge St Paul's, they've discovered the remains of a monastery built around 600 and they are starting to excavate..........even more wonderful things. There is a good gift shop on the way out.Tip: Don't decide to go to McDonald's for free wifi before heading home. We did this but a very kind employee told me (in Italian that I did not understand, so a Manager came over to reiterate in English) that it was not safe to use my iPhone in the store as gypsies frequented the place and stole mobile phones and tables. This was good of them. So we finished and burger and coffee and headed back to Rome on the Metro.

Glorious. The apse, the ceilings, the sheer beauty of this basilica is second to none. We had the chance to attend Mass here standing just a few meters from the tomb of the Apostle St. Paul, there are no words to describe this peaceful spiritual experience.

Magnificent church. I had not been here in many years, but recently found the church was even more magnificent than I remembered. It is absolutely enormous and awe-inspiring, but simpler than many of the other Roman area churches, which lends it a harmonious and peaceful feeling. Your attention goes to the spectacular apse mosaic of Christ and four saints. The ceiling is also beautiful. The courtyard is lovely and you see the sparkling exterior mosaic. This is a "must see" when visiting Rome, along with the three other major basilicas (St. Peter's, St. John Lateran, and St. Mary Major), and is easily reached by metro.

The place of rest of St. Paul. Majestic size with enormous granite columns in the vast court.Inside it is almost empty but the ceilings are amazing, so is the mosaic work.Inside there is a crypt with two parallel staircases, going down to the sarcophagus.Remains of St Paul are buried here in a sealed sarcophagus. His hand cuffs are stored also here, those which were on his hands while theRomans had him prisoned, before decapitating him.The side chapels are very beautiful with inlay wood work. Because Iris empty, it feels kind of strange. As though you are expected to Be where a void will be (heaven?)We were very pleased we made the effort to come here.It is our second time. Last year there were hundreds of people outside the gates,Waiting to come in after two hours. So we gave up.Now, mid February, there were almost no people and we enjoyed our visit Very much.

Tomb of St. Paul. With its rich history and its symbolic meaning, the church holds a lot of importance and is also one of the most visited and important churches around in Rome. This is where St. Paul rests. But getting here requires you to travel a bit from the normal route but the extra mile is totally worth the effort as the sights and the experience itself is rewarding. Also while visiting, it would be great if you could squeeze in a tour of the catacombs as well. There are also food options available
Faboulos. Inside you feel the spirit of Christianity. The mark of St, paul is everywhere. The Tomgb of St.paul is making you to start crying. instant..... the emotions are incredible

Strength, power, and wisdom. If St. Peter's was meant to be marveled at up close, St. Paul's was probably intended to be... respected from a healthy distance. From its massive columns to its papal paintings, St. Peter's is massive, but St. Paul's has a more somber and quietly powerful atmosphere to it. It's a very fitting resting place for a man who was probably the first and most influential Christian intellectual.

Beautiful. Very big, makes a lot of impression and it is really worth to go there and see it. You can find the chains in which St. Paul was kept in capture. At the walls there are pictures of all of the popes, including the current Francesco.
Beautiful church.. Yet another amazing sight to see in Rome with so much history. If you are short on time I would recommend pushing Abbazia di San Paolo Fuori Le Mura to the top of your list.

worth the trip. it is a little out of the way but this church offers a whole lot more than just being one of the main basillicas in Rome. They have artworks all around and the most important fact is that this also has the tomb of St. Paul. The views from up here are wonderful and then there is the visit to the catacombs which brings even more joy to be at the place
the most beautiful church in the world. the most beautiful church in the world, in this church you see all the pope's pictures.. you can pray on the tumb of Saint Paul

Beautiful!. I love this church. Make sure you notice the travertine windows. I don't think I've seen those anywhere else. It's a nice little trip outside the city and make sure you stop at the catacombs while you're out here.

Worth a visit. One of the most important churches of christianity , both in an historical and in a spiritual way .If you are interested in history,arts and you keep visiting churches in Rome then you have to visit San Paolo Fuori Le Mura.It's easy not very far from the general central area of rome.The entrance is free but there are some charges for some services like audio guides etc.There is also a snack bar on the side of the church before you leave hte premises which apparently i did not visit.

Make the effort to go, you'll be glad you did.. One of the four major basilicas in Rome. Beautiful site, captivating historical significance, history of and info on every pope and all their pictures. You get artwork, history, religion, architecture, quiet, beauty and peace.

astonishing. everything about the landmarks are astonishing how it stands like it does and all the restoration work being carried out still is truly amazing, The guide tou bus is fab too with an open air top if required
Wonderfull. We went there a day in december, took the metro line B. A little outside the historycal centre of the city But it worths it. To see

WOW - absolutely beautiful. We enjoyed our visit to the basilica. It is gigantic and absolutely beautiful. The courtyard before you enter is like the courtyards from the old temples. The marble, ceilings and statues and size of the basilica were tremendous. Not many people there at all. Just beautiful.

Tomb of Saint Paul. Saint Paul outside the walls, that’s what it is popularly known as and this church is another important papal churches in Rome that should be in very itinerary. The church has the pictures of all the popes till date and is pretty informative and impressive to look at. The artwork and the architecture of the place is eye captive and make it worth travelling a bit out of the usual tourist path. The church being a bit out of the way is also less crowded.

San Paolo Fuori Le Mura. We spent easily a couple of hours exploring this huge basilica. We had a very nice lunch at a nearby trattoria and came back to the basilica to explore the museum and the underground relics. Must see.
Beautiful. This church is just gorgeous, and well worth the extra minutes it takes to travel to it. There is a metro stop just two minutes away though

A must see attraction in Rome. Saint Paul's church is nothing short of amazing. The ideal thing to do is take the subway getting off at Saint Paul's Subway Station. The Church is about three blocks away. Saint Peter and Saint Paul were originally buried together in in the San Sebastian Catacombs. Early Christians would go to their tombs and have meals. The Church got concerned about the sanctity of their tombs and moved Saint Peter to Saint Peter's Cathedral and moved Saint Paul to the church that was named after him. It is a very impressive church. It is massive and has a lot to see in it. Pilgrams used to come to the church and drop their crosses in a little hole over his tomb. You must see the mosaics, Saint Paul's tomb and the early relics are fantastic.It also has a fantastic gift shop. Afterwards take a cab to the San Sebastian Catacombs and see where they were both originally buried. Then walk down the street and lunch at the utterly fabulous L'Archeologica Restaurant which is beyond fabulous.DougtheLebaneseguy
Interesting!. One of the 4 major basilicas of catholic church. Lovely artwork. The cloister and museum was insteresting as well.

Favorite Church in Rome. This is my favorite church in Rome. It is jaw-dropping as you walked inside. Everything is spectacular, and my favorite was the portraits of all the pope. There was no crowd at all. Although the church is quite far from other tourist attractions, it is really worth the ride to see this.

One of the 7 pelgrim churches of Rome. Churches, churches, churches. You will never enter so many churches in your life, unless you are a Priest of course. Having said this, you just can't miss this one. AND if you are going to pay the entrance for one Cloister, this has to be the one. Take pictures, plan for early lighting if you can and take some black & white shots as well. Great display of all the popes, what will they do after 299? Enjoy!
Wonderful basilica. Beautifully proportioned basilica with beautiful mosaics, paintings and frescoes!Stunning architecture!

Christians this is a MUST Visit. This was my absolute favorite place we visited our whole trip to Rome. It is located a little bit off the hop on hop off your but if you get off at Ciro Massimo stop then you can catch the metro within a couple hundred feet to take three stops down to Bascilla San Paola. It is only a 1/4 mile of so from the metro station. The neighborhood is a little tough so go during daytime. The Bascilla is amazing! The detail, the garden area, the frescos, the size of the structure were all incredible! The crowds were very light because it is off the main tourist sights. Most of ALL, as a Christian, visiting the tomb of Paul is an incredible spiritual opportunity. Just GO! You will not regret it! Lastly, as you exit the Bascilla has a great cafe for wonder lattes and espressos. You will be blessed!
Great treasure. Visted this church in December and was astonished with the place. It has a great histroy and the chains and tomb help to creat a magnificent historic place.
An absolute must-see. This is such a stunning place to visit! I loved every inch of it. Very interesting! Just a little far from the rest of the main attractions in Rome, but well worth the trip
meravigliosa!!!!!. not well-known, but absolutely wonderful and amazing. Don't miss the pictures of all Popes in history, from Peter to Francis ;-)

Great basilica. at least, I thought it was a basilica, not an "abbazia", but this is a detail. If time is short and you have to choose between St Peter's and this, go here. St Peter's has the endless queues, this just has the nice stuff.

Majestic. Check to see when they sing holy vespers with organ accompaniment... it's awesome. There's something about this place, the simplicity of the architecture while also being grandiose that attracts me more than Saint Peter's Basilica.

Impressive. Of course in rome you cannot avoid church because then what is the point of coming to this beautiful city. Out of all the other churches, this one should be on priority for many reasons. For one this is where St. Paul is buried. Second, the view from here is breathtaking and finally the artwork inside is no less to any of the best museums around. Truly spectacular and one of a kind.

spectacular. This is one of many beautiful churches in the city. Really, you don't even have to visit the art and history museums because you can find it all for free inside the churches. This was especially meaningful because St. Paul is buried here.
Night beauty. We visited this place in the night to see the lighting effect on it and belive me this look more beautiful in the night

Simply magnificent. This beautiful basillica is not to be missed. It can be easily reached on the metro, once you step out you can see it in the distance. We spent a lot of time gazing upon the ceiling and at the statues. The highlight being Saint Paul's tomb.
St Pauls Cathedral in Rome. A huge cathedral with Bible motives in paintings, portraits of all the popes, a sarcophage of St Paulus with the Monastery museum and shop

Can't believe I missed this on first. 3 trips to Rome. This is not one of Rome's "must-sees" which is unfortunate considering it's the burial place of St. Paul. I loved this church-- beautiful mosaics, very peaceful inside. The audio guides were quite good-- I would recommend them since there's not much signage. The cloister is original and full of ancient relics.

She said "YES!". I proposed to my (then) girlfriend amongst the collonades in the gardens of Basilica Papale di San Paolo fuori le Mura. We were the only ones there, so we got to keep that moment secret and between the 2 of us forever, without any others watching.One moment of absolute bliss, which I will hold with me for the rest of my life.Basilica Papale di San Paolo fuori le Mura has all the splendour and ornamentation of the other major basilicas in Rome, but without all the tourists. This is a place like no other.
Beautiful. The grand halls here are almost overwhelming. they span more than 100 meters. This is also the burial place of St. Paul. Excellent side trip on the metro

Beautiful church. Really beautiful church, a bit smaller than others but keeps its atmosphere. First time I visited was in 2009, but at that time, I had no time to spend at the church. The visit in the last Oct/2014 was fantastic.
A gem. Just outside The city. Easy to reach by metro. No crowds at all. Very beautiful big Church. Must see. Has the tomb of St Paul's
One of the four major basilicas - 'nuff said. The tomb of the Saint - visit, pray, drink in the reality. Worth the distance and extra effort - by all means.

Really beautiful basilica . This beautiful basilica is much quieter then saint peters and yet it's simple design is just as attractive. Really loved the history of the basilica and the fact that entry was free. The Basilica has a presence about it.. Unlike St. Peter's.
Deserve the firsts place, but for church. Not crowded like in the Vatican, nice place to visit but in my point of view you should consider Colosseum as the top one.

Amazing. a beautiful church. The architecture and the gardens are fantastic
---- Not crowded like the Vatican.

The Cloister was a delightful and peaceful surprise. The historic church burnt in 1853 and was rebuilt according to the original plans. It is a beautiful and impressive basilica. The medallions of the popes lining the top of the walls is interesting and the mosaics in the apse are impressive as are all three entry doors for different reasons.The cloister survived the fire and is lovely with its various curved columns and reminded me of the cloister at Monreale on the outskirts of Palermo, although not quite as beautiful. The historic preservation and archeological excavations are being done in an informative and interesting manner.
See Apostle Paul's Tomb. Not sure why this is ranked #1 on Trip Advisors list. It is definitely a great cathedral and worth the stop, but it ranks lower than St. Peter's and the Colosseum in my book.

Make the effort. Originally founded by Emperor Constantine in the 4th century, the Basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls is the burial place of Saint Paul the Apostle and is one of the five major basilicas of Rome. It is a bit far out so many people never see this wonderful place. Glad we did! It is actually very easy to get to. It is a 10-minute walk from the metro.
St. Paul, Thank you for Sharing the Light. Beautiful, time to reflect and praise God for St. Paul and his mission to share God's Grace thru Jesus Christ our Lord and Savior.

Be with all the popes. Basilica of St. Paul, a beautiful church. It is said to be the burial place for St. Paul who brought christianity to Rome. The basilica have all the popes in mosaic picture ringing the top. The current pope Francis is spotlighted. There are 6 empty frames left for 6 future popes. It is said after the next 6 popes, it will be the end of the world.

The one I liked the most. If you are in your Papal Pilgrimage in the city of Rome, I should say this Basilica was the one that standed the most out of the 4; the art is beautiful and the sights of all the popes made on little pieces of ceramics in the hallways are definitely a must see. Take your time and enjoy

Some history to remember. It’s the place where I could actually, for the first time, associate every pope that there ever was in history with a figure-it’s like their mosaic portraits would be watching over you. No seats, just walk…like walking through the history of Christianity…Unique!

Stunning. Just out of Rome, easily reachable by metro. An oasis of peace, compared to all other main churches in busy Rome.This is the probable burial place of St. Paul, the man who brought christianity to the Roman world. If you are interested in this part of history, a visit to this site is an absolute must.

Vatican Basilicas. We went here are part of a tour of Vatican Basilicas - the tour is worth an afternoon. The church is beautiful, and the history really interesting. If you enjoy after dinner drinks get a bottle of what the monks make there, it is delicious.

Very beautiful church. Although a bit far away from the city center, this beautiful church is definitely worth a visit! It is truly unique and grandiose, but also very charming and peaceful at the same time. It is also the place of St. Paul's grave, so if you are a Christian, this place can be of special importance.

Stunning. Got the Metro: Line B (Get off at Basilica San Paolo) and this is a short walk from the metro station. The church is beautiful and much quieter than the other churches in central Rome. Feel like you can take your time and walk around and appreciate the archieture.
Sublime . Undoubtedly in the same league as The Vatican. Certainly worth the journey to get to. Take the time to sit quietly, hush your mind, and inhale the atmosphere.

Burial place for Saint Paul The. This is a great basilica. The main reason to visit is because It's the burial place for Saint Paul the Apostle. The interior looks very nice as well. Although it's outside the Rome's wall you can easily reach the basilica by using the Metro. Well worth to visit!

Stunning and quiet. Beautiful church with a lot to see and a lot of history - if you are not an expert rent the audio guide - it is very useful and costs only 5 euros and entrance is free. As this is not one of the city's main tourist attractions, it is pretty quiet and you are actually able to walk around in your own pace - very nice experience.

Unforgettable experience. My sister and I came here more as pilgrims than tourists, to see the resting place of the Apostle Paul. I would have loved it even if the church over the tomb had been a small wooden chapel. But the church itself was so lovely, even if not ancient, and I really liked all the paintings of the popes. The grounds are beautiful, as well. It is a bit out of the way, but easy to reach on the Metro, same line as the Colosseum.

Amazing place. Undoubtedly one of the most beautiful places I have visited in the world. If you go to Rome do not miss this amazing place. One tip, not worth doing guided tour, the place is very large and is much more expensive with the guide, if you buy the ticket over the Internet will pay 20 euros.

Too far a trip for this huge church. This church ended up on top of the list of tripadvisor so i decided to give it a try. It is a few stops by the metro and a short walk. But i was not impressed: the dimensions inside are breathtaking but for the rest there is nothing special to this church compared to the older one nearer to the center of Rome. If you do not have a week in Rome to spend, i would skip this one.

A Moving Church. It took us a long time to finally visit this important basilica, and it was well worth it. We had already visited most of the key churches in the city, but still we were not prepared for this one, as it has a very specific feel. We entered through the mosaic-decorated courtyard, then moved to the nave to admire the mosaics of the popes. In all, this church is more about the architectural awe and the symbolism of the mosaics and less about individual artworks as many other churches of Rome. It is well worth the visit. Unfortunately we didn't have time to visit the archaelogical section.

One of the better Churches in Rome. A bit far off from the center, but the Abbazia di San Paolo is worth the trip. While there are some tourists, it is not as crowded as the usual suspects. Take a good walk around the park in front of the church.

A BIG bruiser. The most impressive thing about this church is its sheer size, only smaller than St. Peter's and somehow with cleaner, clearer lines. The negative side of this is the obvious newness which somehow doesn't fit with the rest of Rome.
Great place to see. This was a huge, gorgeous church with very few tourists. We were able to see the burial place of Paul - it was very moving.

A Church to enjoy without many tourists. It's pretty convenient to come by metro and five minutes walk from station to church.Church looks normal from the out side.But once you get to the front door and inside, you can see how magnificent it is.Here is a place that you can stay to pray, meditate, and enjoy the paintings and structures without too many tourist.

Not No. 1. According to Trip Advisor, the Church of Saint Paul Outside the Wall was the number one attraction in Rome. I wanted to see what this church had over St. Peter’s. It is huge with a lovely parterred courtyard and columns surrounding it and a huge statue of St. Paul in the center. The inside while beautiful was not in my opinion as magnificent as St. Peter’s. I would definitely not give it a number one rating. There were some very beautiful paintings here. We especially liked the frescoed portraits of all the popes located high on the surrounding walls. The one of Pope Francis had a light shining on it. The church was built by Constantine on the site of St. Paul’s burial and has undergone several reconstructions. It was a little bit out of the way and took about 40 minutes to get there from the city center. It was very interesting, but if time is limited, I would go to St. Peter's instead.
Beautiful. We went here to see St. Paul's tomb and the reliques in the museum. The inner garden is very peaceful and nic . It was easy to reach the church by Metro line B .
Paolo. there are pictures of all the popes, I like it more than st. peter's cathedral in vatican. close to the metro station.

historic site worth the ride out on subway. An absolutely beautiful basilica overwhelming in its size. For me the most important thing was St. Paul's tomb. It's worth the price to visit the cloister, museum and archeological digs also. No charge for the church, of course.

A beautiful place well worth a visit. This roman basilica was unfortunately destroyed in a fire in the 19th century but was rebuilt along original lines in very good taste. There is a courtyard not affected by the fire, which is probably the most beautiful in Rome. I visited as a child and my revisit fulfilled all my expectations.

No queue.. The church is really easy to get to (metro stop with the same name) and there are not many turists visiting it. Don't forget to bring your camera!
Also - if you forget to dress respectfully, you can buy some kind of "blankets" to cover yourself outside (but you may look really funny).
Great Religeous Site. The best part is that there are no line ups and yet the basilica is almost as large as st. Peters and just as beautiful.

Magnificent. Rome offer Churches and Cathedrals so fantastic and wonderful . Rome is magic this place is magic. The tombstone bears the Latin inscription PAULO APOSTOLO MART ("to Paul the apostle and martyr")

Unique. This church houses st.paul's chain, it's 260 portraits of popes, egyptian alabasters and Byzantine door. To be fair, I was there because St. Paul is my favorite apostle and it is unique in its own way.
Massive.. Sit at the back. Take it all in for a while. All the popes are along the upper ring. Fairly easy to get by bus !
Fantastic. A must see.. All Four Basilicas are a must see.Saint Paul's is on the outskirt of town and shouldn't be missed. Saint John's is another that should not be missed.

There with the best. Truth to tell, it is unfair to expect to visit every attraction and not to have some of them being repaired. By the time we got to this church I was suffering from the tourist equivalent of shell shock. And in fairness to them all, all are very beautiful in their own way. The workmanship and religious devotion expressed is palpable. However, after a week of eating delicious and exquisite chocolates the palate becomes more than jaded. This is solely my fault and to "do" Rome again I would be far more discriminating in my choice of venues. It is perhaps wrong of me to vent this on this particular church, which is wonderfully illustrative of its genre and it would be too easy to say if you've seen one Baroque example, you've .... but I guess this is what one comes to expect in Rome or Venice or Florence. Absolutely delightful.I will definitely look on Scelig Michael in a different light.
Beautiful. Highly recommend to go due to the sheer size of it. The gardens outside are lovely. I have fond memories of going to this church
Breathtaking . While I was in Rome, I made the time to visit many churches and this is by far one of my favourite! Beautiful on the outside and inside, I definitely recommend a visit.

Beautiful church. This cathedral "Fuori le mura" is outside the original Rome walls, but accessible through the subway. It is the second largest after St Peter. Beautiful in the inside with a lot of paintings. St Pauls tomb is inside together with the chains from his captivity.

On of the most beautiful churches in the world. We visited San Paolo after visiting San Pietro first. The queue on San Pietro was immense. In San Paolo on the other hand there was hardly anybody. Wondering around in the magnificent basilica without a crowd was a great experience. I even prefer San Paolo over San Pietro.At 18 pm there is a mass and around 17.30 pm the lights are switched on so you can see the mosaics of the triumphal arch and the large apse mosaic in there bright colours. Otherwise you have to put 1 euro to illuminate. The entrance is free. If you want to see the cloister, the small museum and the archeological site there is a fee of 4 euro. You get value for your money. This basilica is certainly a must see when you visit Rome.
Just a church. It's nothing really special. The roof was pretty nice. It's close to Metro. But if you're super far away, you're not missing anything.

Worth the ride outside the city walls!. It's a huge church outside the main historical area but it it is reachable by Metro, stop at San Paolo. It is beautiful. Loved everything about it. Worth the ride!

Worth to visit. One of the Mayor Basilicas of Rome, is not far away and there is a bus and a subway station 5 min walking from the main entrance.Check the missing pictures for the next´s Popes (its been said that once the pictures are all full will be the world´s end...)
A place full of spirituality. A place full of spirituality. A place where you energized for a long time from now. I liked everything (including proximity).

Loved it. I loved this church. its big, peaceful, great architecture, amazing wall pai tings and statues .... I loved everything about it.P.S. I have visited this week many churches. And on the door we saw a man wearing black holding a small basket. At first we used to put money in the basket thinking that this is a priest taking offerings for the church...then we were told that these aren't priests, they are beggers....so dont give them money please, Unless u want to...

Huge church but not the best in Rome. St Paul's outside the Walls is a relatively beautiful church and certainly extremely huge, but I found it rather sterile when compared to other churches in Rome. Most of what you see comes from the 1800s from reconstruction after a fire. It is, in my opinion, just too large for what you find inside. In any other city I would have rated much this higher but in Rome there are just so many other fabulous churches to see. I do not see how anyone can rate this higher than St Peters.The cloister are worth a visit and are very unique. They did not get destroyed in the fire and date from the 1200s.There is a small fee to see the cloisters.If you have a week then it is worth visiting. Otherwise unless you are a Catholic and are on a Pilgrimage of Churches and sacred places then give this one a miss.I visited first thing in the morning before continuing on to Ostia Antica. You can easily do both in he morning if you get an early start.

Magnificent - Goosebumps. We were in Rome for 1 week and our first visit was at the Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls on a Sunday afternoon. The Basilica is very beautiful: out of the many churches, musea and historical locations we visited that week, this was the only experience giving me goosebumps. Only a few people were visiting this large Basilica, giving you lots of space and time to observe.Paintings of all popes are available close to the ceiling. The most impressive are the ceiling of the nave, the mosaics of the triumphal arch and the large apse mosaic (Christ flanked by the Apostles Peter, Paul, Andrew and Luke). There are a souvenir shop and cafetaria just outside the Basilica.It`s located a bit outside the historical centre. Taxis can be found where the Viale Ferdinando Baldelli crosses the Viale Leonardo da Vinci.Highly recommended!

astonishing!. i've been in Rome a billion times and i've always been "segregated" to the mainstream attractions..this time, with a renovated sprinkle of curiosity I decided to follow others' suggestions here on tripadvisor.this abbazia is so astonishingly gorgeous, it leaves you breathless as soon as you get inside it! furthermore, there was no queue under the burning hot summery sun at all (maybe because I managed to get there at a quarter to 6 pm, after a bit of a hussle with the unpredictable roman public transportation, but it was well worth it)!!!useful tip for low-cost travellers: if you have some spare time and you want to rest your feet, on the way back to the city centre take the bus number 271, it's a cheap ride (in alternative to the turistic buses) which brings you around the Colosseum, Piazza Venezia, Trastevere, Castel Gandolfo, Saint Peter's basilica... I was myself surprised how beautiful was the route!! (and I paid the price of a single ticket, 1.50 euros!)
"Too marvelous for words". The magnificence and grandeur of the Basilica are indescribable. It is outside of the historical area, but well worth the taxi ride

trully tranquil!. Though ranking the churches may seem absurb but, on the ecclesiastical status standpoint, this is #3 out the 4 papal basilicas (please correct me if I'm wrong) in the Roman Catholic Church. Unparalleled status! It could be a little far away and probably because of this, you could avoid crowds and have a very peaceful moment in this spectacular basilica, and pay tribute to San Paolo's relics!

Imperial piece of art, Spirituality and history. Loved the interior and exterior ,very different than all the basallicas.The exterior corridor along with statue and garden was treat to eyes. It was so peaceful compared to all the spiritual places in Italy.It is very near to metro station and you should not miss it.

Loved it..Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls. Easy to access by metro and worth the trip. What a magnificent church and garden area. Rich in history, very few tourists, reportedly the burial site of Saint Paul and the second largest church in Rome (after St. Peter's) and a nice place to rest for some quiet contemplative time away from the madness of central Rome. Nothing else nearby at all so just get back on the metro or bus and head back to the city. Or take the metro up one stop and visit the Centrale Montmartini Museum.

Not on a tourist list. Although the Sistine Chapel is touted as the most magnificent in this city of sacred history, the Basilica of Saint Paul and the Ignatian Cathedral rival in aesthetics. The #171 bus has a stop out front, and can also be accessed from Termini Station.

Papal History and Art without the crowds. When researching from my third visit to Rome I noted to my suprise that St Paul Outside the Walls was the number one attraction on tripadvisor. I had actually not heard of it so thought it might be worth a look because of these recommendations. I would not put it number one on my list for things to do in Rome but I am certainly glad that it was recommended so highly on tripadvisor. The Basilica is replete with papal history and is well worth visiting.The Basilica is a little way from central Rome but still easily accessible by Metro. We took Metro Line B from Cavour (1.50 Euro ticket each) getting off at the Basilica San Paolo station. I recall the way to the basilica was not immediately obvious from the station and that the area looked a little grotty with graffiti and tatty looking market stalls. But one exits the Metro on the viale Ferdinando Baldelli near the intersection with via Ostiense. Turn right onto via Ostiense and one will see the sign pointing to the basilica. The church looks a little plain and uninspiring from this side until the main facade at the Piazzale San Paolo is reached.St Paul's is one of the four ancient papal basilicas, being an important church since at least the time of Constantine. The basilica was destroyed in the fire of 1823 and rebuilt, but much of the historic pieces still remain. Central to the basilica is the tomb of St Paul dating from circa 67AD, and here one can view the large sarcophagus and marble tombstone (I believe these date from the 4th century). On display are also chains said to be those used during St Paul's imprisonment in Rome. This is an interesting site for the religious and history buffs alike.Above the tomb is the magnificent baldachino dating from 1285 completed by Arnolfo di Cambio (c1240-1310) who also completed the bronze statue of St Peter in San Pietro, one foot of which has been rubbed to a sharp, shiny point by pilgrims over the years. di Cambio's work can be seen in all the papal basilicas of Rome and many other churches in the city. Also impressive here is the the enormous candelabrum for the Paschal candle decorated with scenes of the Passion and Resurrection in marble by Pietro Vassalletto in the 12th century. The important remains of the medieval basilica which survived the fire of 1823 is the the triumphal arch with the apse mosiacs by Venetian artists dating from 1220. The transept and nave were destroyed in 1823 but have been beautifully restored. The 19th century ceilings are glorious and the mosaic medallion portraits of every pope is an interesting adornment , a feature arranged by Leo the Great in the fifth century and added to up to the present, Benedict XVI's being the most recently added.At the end of the nave can be seen three monumental doors. The central door of green bronze, inlaid with a silver cross, depicts scenes from the lives of St Peter and St Paul and dates from 1931. The shiny gold bronze door on the right (as one looks from the outside) is the Holy Door which dates from the Jubilee Year of 2000. On the inside of the basilica the counter facade to the Holy Door is the original main door dating from 1070 which was commissioned in Constantinople and contains 54 panels in damascene silver with scenes of the life of Christ.One of the most impressive features of the Basilca is outside, namely the front facade. There is a delightful quadriportico with 150 columns surrounding a pretty and restful garden dominated by a large 19th century statue of St Paul. The facade's mosiacs completed in 1874 are bright and photogenic depicting the prophets Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and Daniel, then above a central section representing the Lamb of God and the 12 Apostles, finally Christ surrounded by Peter and Paul are at the apex.Entrance to the basilica is free and there is a gift shop where one can experience the usual Italian reluctance to provide change (we bought two small souvenirs for 6 Euros and the shopkeep was pained to have to give change for a 10 Euro note ! Why don't Italians want to give change!? They want exact fare, but then everything is usually 6,7, 9, 12 or 14 Euros, so change is required if one is to pay exact fare. The Catch 22 is that no one is prepared to give you said change anywhere so that you can pay the exact amount! One has to horde 1 and 2 Euro coins like a miser when in Rome to pay for anything. Surely a papal basilica, an outlet of the wealthy Vatican, can afford to get change for their cash registers. I found this all over Rome - the Vatican Museum, busy attractions, small and large shops). The only downside of the basilica was the surprisingly run down, ragged and rubbish strewn Parco Ildefonso Schuster at the front of the property. I wonder if this is separate from the church's authority and is maintained by the city council instead.The Basilica was a wonderful main point of interest during a morning of sight seeing in a less visited part of town. One could, as we did, get back on the Metro two stops back to Piramide station to then see the Pyramid of Caius Cestius, the beautiful non-Catholic cemetery and the Porta San Paolo.

Worth going outside the walls. Rome has a plethora of churches so it takes a rather special basilica to lure the average Joe "outside the walls" of the ancient city. St Paul's or Basilica Papale di San Paolo fuori le Mura is just such a church. It's a vast building but the lack of chairs makes it seem even larger. The exterior has a distinctly tropical feel with palm trees, delicately maintained gardens and peach and yellow colored frescoes. The inside uses the same color scheme but the walls are adorned with portraits of Popes up to and including Benedict XVI. The church wasn't around during the reign of St Peter or the next dozen or so Bishops of Rome. In fact construction didn't begin on the site until the 4th century when a structure was built over the tomb of St Paul. Since then it has gone through several overhauls to repair damage caused by menaces ranging from earthquakes to Saracen invaders. Consequently, it oozes history whilst looking a tad newer and fancier than some of the other basilicas such as St John Lateran. The church has a very relaxed ambiance that is in stark contrast to the hustle and bustle of St Peter's and frankly most of the other sites in Rome. You don't have to be profoundly religious to enjoy the basilica but if you are of the religious persuasion you might be interested to get a glimpse of St Paul's tomb which is visible below the altar. Despite being outside the ancient walls, St Paul's is very easy to get to on the underground metro. Even if you don't speak Italian, it doesn't take a linguistic genius to figure out that you need to get off at the stop called Sao Paolo. There aren't a lot of bars or restaurants in the vicinity but there is a McDonalds that has a rooftop terrace from where you plot your next excursion. Despite the intense competition, the basilica is my favorite church in all of Rome.

You actually enter from the back of the church (make sure to go out the other side and don't miss the front/courtyard view of the outside!) The church was rebuilt in the early 1800's after a fire but much was restored and much was added. The burial ground of St. Paul is in the center and a small portion is unearthed for viewing. There was a small mass occurring during our visit so the chanting was lovely. Good luck for all of us!!! :) It is AMAZING!!! A must see.

An Important Basilica but not so well known.. There has been a few churches situated here over the centuries and out the back there are some remains relating back to the initial churches.
