While it is an important church there were very few visitors there when we visited it. It is situated in an attractive garden and inside it is impressive with its columns and ceiling art. A complete contrast to the Vatican which was visited the previous day, quieter and more relaxing and one does not feel rushed for time. I do suggest before you come you find out something about its long history to appreciate it more.There is also a nice cafe out the back.

Dont miss that Basilica!!!. if you pass through Rome, please don't miss this! It's wonderfull!!! I guess it's nice to see, second time in town, and i cannot miss it. a big park is located just in front of the basilica. we had a pic nic there. the beauty inside was incredible. the fantastic images that reproduce the popes all around simply amazing. the museum inside is quite cheap. then the evening is full of little places to eat well. just in fornt of the basilica there is a mac donald for those on a budget, and also another fast food restaurant with grilled meat. but if you want to walk five minutes I recommend a typical Italian trattoria Burro&Sugo of which I will write more later. we could not see the catacombs new I had read. within us the image of St. Paul would be the oldest. but will next time. in fact I will definitely return.
What beauty. A lovely church, with the portraits of the popes around the upper walls. A lovely gift shop as well, with religious and non-religious objects.

Include this in your itinerary..... Visit this monument for the interiors and be wowed by the massive columns, intricate and gorgeous ceiling art. Having been to Rome a few times now, I have come to appreciate it even more and humbly think that this is worth making a trip for!
Rome 2013. Fantastic monument to visit. Beautiful basilicum. It is even with many visitors around very relaxing to visit the [art outside of the basilicum.

Impressive. Big church with lots of details. Also the garden is beautiful and a nice place to be. Don't forget to look at the back of the church when you are in the garden. There is a little shop attached, for souvenirs but also a simple drink.
Make the trip if you have time. I visited St Paul Outside the Walls on my first visit to Rome. The front door is amazing! The inside is beautiful too.

Huge beautiful space. It is one of the stupidities of TA that this lovely church ranks top sight and 'must-do' in Rome, above St peter's, the Vatican, the Coliseum etc etc. But it is a lovely and unusual tranquil space with its 80 pillars - although most of what you see is only 19th century - rebuilt after a terrible fire. And the site of the saint's tomb is specially revered.

Totally worth the visit..!!!. Even though may people don't visit this place, it is one of the great basilica in Rome with amazing and impressive surrounding. It is bit far from the city center. But you can easily get in to there. I really recommend this place as a must see wonder in Rome

Absolutely incredible.... This a must see in Rome. This Basilica is enormous! The columns are fantasitic and ceiling is eye-popping. You really just want to sit down and stare. After seeing all the major Basilica's in Rome, this is definetly 1 or 2 in my book. Not that easy to get to.(Take the subway or Taxi) and the outside isn't as beautiful as some of the others, but the inside is worth the trip! Chow.

Peaceful and beautiful. St. Paul's is a little further away from most of the other tourist locations, but it is well worth an extra stop or two on the metro. The entrance where we arrived was very plain. Inside, however, we were in awe of the beauty. There was a feeling of spirituality at every corner. Many of my favorite pictures of Rome were taken here. Take time to check out the items in the gift shop and go into the courtyard. There you will find a beautiful statue of St. Paul, palm trees, a beautiful wooden door, and artwork near the top of the roof. It is a serene place where you can meditate, pray or admire God's work.

Grandiose. This is the second largest church in the Rome area and is definitely worth the visit. You can get to it easily on the Metro (Line B, S. Paolo stop). There are a couple of really great features of this church. One is the portraits of all the popes, from Peter to Francis, along the top part of the walls. Below the altar is the tomb of St. Paul and (traditionally) the chains with which he was bound. Anyone can go down the steps near the tomb and leave a Mass intention in the box. There is a lovely courtyard and the gift store is really nice with loads of articles handmade in Italy. Look especially at the hand carved olive-wood crosses. This is a wonderful church to visit.

Worth the visit. Most people do not visit this church because it is not inside the historic centre. Beautiful artwork, mosaic sculpture. My personal favourite is the windows made of alabaster. Also, make sure you check out the gift shop with products made from the Benedictine monks including a version of nutella and liquors like absinthe.

Magnificent. The Bastillica is one of the main 4 in Rome and is huge the best part after walking around the Bastillica was the extra part to the Cloisters and museum it was 4€ but well worth it. Very interesting and well presented
Great basilica. Worth of visit.. Great basilica. Inside it is so much free space. It is worth visit. There is a bar, restaurant and toilet facilities.
nice place. will surely drop by if I'll return to this lovely city. Loved the people and the service was excellent.

La Traviata in an amazing church setting. Go to the opera offerings at this church. The performances are amazingly wonderful. We have attended a series of arias and also operas. The talent is first rate and even the best tickets are so very reasonable. One of those Rome experiences that is a must!!!
Spiritual ground. The house of Catholicism, this is the right place to say your prayers and feel the Divine. You can check architectural characteristics, landmarks and live part of Cristian faith.
Amazing. What a great church! Very few people visit because of the distance from the city. I was able to roam around without hundreds of people chatting. Very quite place. Great artwork on the doors.

Excellent surprise. We visited the church as an improvisation, in a rainy morning, after the original target (the Museo della Civilta Romana) was found closed without warning. There is a metro station on the line B, San Paolo, very close to the church. The building itself is a very large, very impressive structure, a basilica wiht 2x2 aisles, but the senzation of space is more intensive than in the San Giovanni in Lateran (the pillars are round korinthian columns, and not rectangular, wall-type structures). There is a fine cloister, and a big, colonnade-limited courtyard. My finest surprise on my first Rome-trip.
Truly Memorable. This place was awe inspiring. To see the resting place of St. Paul was so amazing. The church was very intimate, very unlike St. Peter Basilica.

Amazing Church. The Basilica is off the beaten track but is easlly accessible using the Metro. The church itself is huge and is beautiful. If you are Catholic/Christian this is a must view site to visit in Rome.

Visiting Basilica di San Paulo. Visited Basilica di San Paulo during our week long stay in Rome. As many other reviewers have said, this church is off the beaten path of tourist attractions, and for anyone going to spend more than a day in Rome is what you want. In fact, we took the subway down to the closest stop and walked the block or two to the church. Once inside, it is nothing short of breathtaking. The church itself is probably the size of a football field, and the beauty inside speaks for itself. The main attraction is of course, Paul's tomb which is located towards the front of the church. Once at the tomb, you can see where his tomb was cut out of the marble and set behind a grated fence. Just to have the ability to stand and view the tomb of one of the Bible's greatest preachers was breathtaking! What many people do not know is the fact Rome was/is split between those who followed St. Paul and those who followed St. Peter. Sadly enough, both men served and gave their life for Jesus Christ and the ministry of God's word.In closing, if you're a Christian who knows or have read Paul's writings (13 books in the New Testament) in the Bible, and don't stop at this church, you have missed out on a once in a lifetime chance in history. I would also suggest visiting the "Tre Fontane Abbey" which is the location of where St. Paul was beheaded. I could not see one without the other!God Bless!
Crowds!. The Holy Father was in the city the day we went so it was a mob scene. However that just adds to the excitement.
Very beautifull church. St. Paul Outside the Walls it's an amazing church. Even it is not in the center of Rome, people should visit it.

Great place that doesn't feel touristy. I thought the interior here was really cool as well as the exterior. It's not far from the metro station so it's easy to access. It's nice going to a place and feeling like you're exploring it and not having the chaos all around.

burned. Though burned entirely and then rebuilt by the French in the early part of the last century, the medieval surviving cloister is one of the best in Europe (did I say Europe? I meant the world)>
great pilgrimage. being at the tomb of st paul is beyond moving and the decor is amazing, its far from the city center but there is a metro stop on b line very close to the basilica

The Best in Rome. In a city replete with beautiful churches, this is one not to miss. Just steps away from the Metro, this church has it all: paintings, mosaics, relics and tombs all surrounded by Neo-classical symmetry. Mass is held every hour. There is a fine snack bar. A great place to spend a couple of hours touring and being..

Awe-inspiring!. If you like visiting churches, as I do, and you happen to be in Rome, DO NOT miss St. Paul Outside the Walls. From the medallions depicting every Pope from Peter top Francis, to the 30 foot tall Easter Candle holder, to the wonderful statue of St. Paul in the entry yard, I was just delighted. One of the four major basilicas of Rome, it was an easy Metro ride from our hotel near Castel Sant' Angelo. Put this magnificent church high on your list of things to see.

Go if you are filling in a rainy day. It is very easy to get to this basilica - just take the Metro B line and get off at fhe St Paolo station. This brings you to the back and side of the church. Keep walking until you get around to the front of the church. We did not do this, and felt cheated by the lack of garden as the pictures on TA showed. Ot was only upon leaving that we found the entrance - beautiful.The inside of the church was impressive. In particular, the long aisles of arches. The walls and ceilings show St Paul's life. Alrhough easy to get to, and interesting inside, this church is only one of many.

Words can't describe....... The thing that struck me most was the incredible craftsmanship and time that went into building this place of worship. The colors, the detail, floor to ceiling, you'd have to see it yourself. It's not something to walk through, sit down, spend the time to take it all in.
a real dream!!. If you pass through Rome, even for a little little time... please don't miss this! It's awesome!!! I guess it's nice to see, wonderful to see once again!!!
Don't miss it. It's part of the Vatican and easy to reach by bus. It's unusual and uplifting. Most imposing. And there's a lovely pharmacy.

Our favorite church in Rome. Of course we visited St. Peters (and several other churches on the tourist circuit) but we found this the most interesting church -- and also the most pleasant to visit (because so few tourists manage to find it), although it's actually easy to get to (it has it's own Metro stop).The architecture (it's a huge church), mosaics of popes, and the tomb of St. Paul are must-sees -- and the absence of crowds gives you lots of time for reflection.Don't overlook the garden and statue of St. Paul at the front. This is easy to do, because the walk from the subway takes you to a side entrance.

Stunning. It may be a little out of the way, but St. Paul Outside the Walls is a must see. Absolutely gorgeous inside. Be sure and look at the mosaic of Pope Francis (and yes, all the pope portraits are mosaics!).

Amazing architecture and history. St. Paul Outside the Walls is absolutely beautiful. There were hardly any tourists when I visited it and it was as if I had the place to myself. The grounds of the Basilica of Saint Paul are well-maintained and the interior of the church is breathtaking. I highly recommend that you visit it while in Rome.
Not to miss!. Its a wonderful church, next to the metro station. And the best thing is that there aren´t that many visitors. A must see! :)
Impressive and beautiful!. One of the bigger churches in Rome and a really beautiful one. Situated a bit otside of the city center, but worth the trip -recommended!

A must see!. This is a beautiful basilica just outside the main attractions in Rome that contains the tomb of Saint Paul under the alter, which you can partially see. It is easy to get to on the metro B line, exiting at the Basilico San Paolo exit and walking a brief 10 minutes. It is amazing inside and so much to see. Portraits of Popes encircle the basilica and Pope Francis is already up there. You must enter from the front to really get the full effect. We entered from the side and almost missed the beauty of the gardens and front entrance. There is also a nice gift shop and a small cafe just outside as well. It is a beautiful and peaceful site to visit, don't miss this!!

Beautiful Gardens Outside. I knew beforehand that this was a fairly new church as it had been rebuilt due to a fire. I went to pilgrimage to what is believed to be the tomb of St Paul which is very unique and impressive, but inside the church there isn't much more to leave you in awe. Then I walked outside another door and into a garden where a large statue of St Paul stood and was just amazed, it was a beautiful garden where you could almost just see and admire the greenery. Between these two things it was well worth the visit.

Visit to Rome. The history surrounding this beautiful cathedral! Its beauty! Our tour guide, one of the best tour guides in Rome, took us through this historical structure and enlightened us on how it came to be, as well as its name, St. Paul Outside the Walls. We loved it!

The most impressive to me.... St Paul is the patron saint of the City of London & most notable building is his Cathedral) so i really wanted to visit his 'tomb' & church...& well worth it was too!!! The journey was via metro just outside City..when we first saw the building i wasn't impressed but ghosh when you go inside..it is 'HUGE' & so beautifully decorated...it was breath taking 'folks..go visit..loved the front of the church & the cafe was superb & sold great coffee!!!

Impressive!. Impreesive srvice, impressive space, paintings, everything! Overwhealming, like everything in Rome!
Very easy to get there by Metro.

From the road to Damascus to via Ostiense. There is no real pilgrimage to Rome if the tomb of St. Paul is not included.
Since It is located outside the city center there is no crowd at all.

The 2nd largest of the four papal basilicas. We would have never seen it had it not been for our guide. He brought us to this beautiful basilica that was built over the burial site of St. Paul. I am so glad that he did. Here is where you can see the tomb of St. Paul under the altar, as well as the links of chain that are believed to be his prison chains. It's a beautiful sight from the moment you enter the courtyard. As you're in the courtyard, you will see the statue of St. Paul and the colorful gold mosaic of Christ with the two apostles by his side. Then there's the large central door of the basilica which tells some biblical stories. It has panels with various scenes of St. Peter and St. Paul. To the right of the central door is one of four Holy Doors. It's a door that is only opened during Jubilees. The interior of the church is even more ornate than the exterior. The gold coffered ceilings, the papal portraits, and the colorful mosaics are all very impressive. The border of papal portraits is truly unique to this basilica. Every pope has a picture. The current pope's picture is always illuminated. Pope Benedict's portrait was lit up at the time of our visit. Do take the time to visit the Basilica of St Paul Outside the Walls. It actually turned it out to be a very memorable visit. One that I will never forget.
Excellent. Excellent, wonderful visit, you must see it, Access by metro and ten minutes walk. It is impressive. Go early in the morning to avoid crouds.

Worth it!. This church was recommended to us by three seminary students we met in St. Peters square. They said it was worth it, and were spot on. It's off the beaten path, but worth seeing. The inside is huge and beautifully decorated. Pictures of all the popes encircle the entire inside of the building. Only a few empty spaces left. Although it was December, the gardens were still well maintained and actually in bloom. A perfect spot to sit back, relax and reflect. Even the on site cafe was nice, the staff friendly and very resonably priced. We stopped in a coffee and pastry and enjoyed the entire experience. Oh, and no entrance fees.
worth the effort to find it. We were lucky to tour this beautiful church with a guide named Liz and 30+ US priests. There was a display of notes that Pope John XXIII (soon to be saint) had written.

Off the Beaten Path, but worth the trip!. Beautiful basilica with interesting history and architecture. Garden outside the building with huge statue of St. Paul. There are pictures of each of the popes along the ceiling of the basilica.

One of the four main Basilicas. Not to be missed. We took a taxi here as it was a little far from our hotel. We did the audio tour for 5 Euro and was well worth it. The basilica was beautiful and the grounds were as well. The garden out back was wonderful with the multicolored columns. The history is fascinating. Don't miss this.

Visit and pay respect... Understatedly beautiful; doesn't have the grandeur of St. Peter's but has all the beautiful elements of a great church. As I write this review, I am almost guilty of having tourists mob this place. It's beautiful holy church and hate to see cramming tourists just taking pictures all over the place without reverence to the place.

Such a beautiful calm place. Even though this beautiful amazing cathedral is a little distance away from the main city centre, its a short bus ride or a train away from most of Rome and its definitely worth it. Its quite surreal stepping inside such a magnificent place, and you definitely need quite a bit of time to take it all in. Its light and easy to capture some great photos and the garden outside is just lovely. Definitely recommend going here at least once on your trip to Rome - you wont regret it.

Beautiful!. I am not religious at all, however, I enjoy visiting some historic churches. This is a beautiful cathedral. It was not especially busy when I visited. If you enjoy historic churches, you wont want to miss this one!

St. Paul on a cold and rainy day. An interesting place to visit, not the place to visit on a cold and rainy day. So much history to see in Rome, and a definite place to go back and visit on a warm day.

Very nice. Beautiful cathedral, but away from the main tourist area which made it so calm and a pleasure to wander around. Décor magnificent but refined. Could have sat there for hours soaking up the atmosphere!

Quite inspirational. This is one of the four major churches in Rome but it is a little off the beaten track. However we really were keen to seek it out so caught the train from Colosseo Metro. Cost 1.50 euros each and the machine only takes coins so buy an icecream to get change! The train is the Laurentino Line B, just four stops to San Paulo Basilca stop. It was an easy transition.The church is huge and relatively unadorned but very elegant. The original church built during the time of Constantine was destroyed by fire in the 1800s so this one is quite recent in comparison to many others. There are many wonderful statues and likenesses of St Paul everywhere. The huge bronze door depicting many scenes from Scripture is one of the treasures of Rome and was made in the 11th century in Istanbul.The supposed tomb of St Paul is much venerated. There is a case containing a chain which illustrates Paul's imprisonment in Rome. Below that is the sarcophagus where Paul is reputed to have been laid after death. It was a great place to visit with very few tourists.
So beautiful. This is a must church. It is second biggest in Rome and I like it more than St Peters, so beautiful, especially exterior.

Just take the Metro to Basilica S. Paulo stop. walk 200 mt. and you are in an gorgeous place. There is the huge Basilica, the gardens, the excavations. Only to the archaeological site there is a fee entrance.Everything in Rome seems huge, but here you can learn the meaning of huge. It's a Historic site and a must see also for non believers. Also in the Vatican web site there is a virtual tour to this Basilica. Enjoy.

Lovely, Quiet, and Worth the Visit. I had friends tell me to go check this out as I love architecture, history, and beautiful gardens. It is a little outside of the action of central Rome but we took the Metro (subway) and there is a stop that is within a few blocks of the Basilica. The architecture is gorgeous and it seems each part of the Basilica has something of wonderful historical significance ranging in age from several hundred years ago to just a few years ago. The central altar and tomb of St. Paul is very spiritual and beautiful. The gardens and outside spaces are immaculate, well cared for and colorful. There is also an archaeological site on premises if you want to pay a couple extra euros to see it. Otherwise, there is no charge and NO crowds. This was a lovely break from the crowds, hustle and bustle of downtown Rome.

Great for a 2nd trip to Rome or Paulist. This is the site of the tomb of the great apostle Paul. The Basilica is of gargantuan proportions, and unlike St.Peter's, if you get there in the morning, it is almost completely empty. It is in the suburbs so you have to take a car to get there. It was worth it. 5/7 of my family liked it better than St. Peter's because of the empty space and the quiet ancient tomb. You feel like you've been let in in a secret. However there aren't the famous "name" art as St. Peter's. We spent about 45 minutes looking around. There is a snack bar, washrooms, and a gift shop too.

Worth the Trip. Its a bit out of the way, but worth the trip. The church itself is Huge and the sculptures and architecture are amazing. For those religious travelers, being able to see the burial area of Saint Paul was an experience I will never forget.

God's 2nd home. Words are not enough to say how incredible it was to be at such a historic site and although I am not religious I would say that those that are where not pushing their religion down your throught but rather sharing their love.
Amazing. If you only go to one church in Rome make it this one the ceiling is awesome, not to be missed , worth the 50 cents to illuminate the central dome

Beautiful Church. I took the Metro to St. Paul's and it was an easy walk from the station to the back of the church. What a beautiful place! Majestic is the word which comes to mind. It is a peaceful place, uncrowded, and absolutely gorgeous. I would visit again on my next trip to Rome.

Awesome place. When we arrived in Rome we were wondering why the whole area is named after Saint Paul. After visiting this church we understood.
It is almost as big as Basilica San Pietro. No queue at the entry (we were there on Friday afternoon), we could take pictures (no flash), you can pray in silence. very quiet

Rome. This is a church fall out of the tours map. Don't be put off. It will surprise you.First of all, there is NO line up. You can say your prayer in quiet. Have a quiet time after all the glossiest historic site. I don't mean this is not as glory as the other one. It has all the greatness but it's only " outside the wall" .

Superb. I disliked the queues to enter. First go to the museum and take your time. See capella sixtina for sure and the go the St. Peter's Basillica. Do not buy souvenirs from there - too expensive. Nice pizzeria in a small alley.

out of the way but worth a visit. St Pauls outside the walls is a bit out of the city, may need to get a taxi to it, but it is well worth a visit. As you walk around the city each church all come together as one, this one is outside the city and does not have many people walking around it which makes it special. There was no queue to get into it and it hosts St Pauls burial spot.

So quiet, prayerful and beautiful. Of the many, many churches in Rome, St. Paul's outside the Walls should not be left off your list. Don't be put off by modern exterior. Truly felt the presence of St. Paul, least of the apostles but greatest evangelist of Christ.

An inspiring place with beautiful cloisters. Although what you see is a 19th century rebuilding after a terrible fire, this church is still an awesome sight. The huge nave, leading to steps which take you down to St. Paul's burial site, impresses by its height and columns. It's well worth paying the 4 Euros to visit the cloisters, which escaped the fire. Tranquil and beautiful - it was lovely having them nearly to ourselves in the warm October sun.

Marvellous!. This is my second visit to Rome, and as I have some spare time before going to the airport, I decided to go and take a look at the church (it's ranked 2nd attractions in Rome in Tripadvisor, anyway!). Compared to Basilica St Peter, Basilica St Paul may not be as popular, but it is truly a hidden gem of Rome. No queue, this beautiful and peaceful church is all for you to walk, touch and feel the hundred years of holy history. I have been to several churches in Europe before, but have to say I am really impressed with the interior architecture and the atmosphere at Basilica St Paul and feel so lucky that I visited it! Take the metro blue line and you'll be there at Basilica St Paolo station within 10 minutes from Roma Termini, and another 5 minute walking you'll easily find the church there!

Glad our tour included this stop. I assume not a lot of people know about this hidden gem. The only reason we did was because our tour (Dark Rome through Viator) took us there. It's quite different from being in St. Peter's Basillica as it is peaceful without so many tourists. There is a very nice gift store and cafe on site.

Gorgeous church without the crowds of St. Peter's. We happened to be staying near by, so it was an easy car ride for us to get to St. Paul's. It is beyond gorgeous, it has interesting details and architectural elements that make it different from all the other churches, and best of all- hardly any crowd.

Beautiful Basilica!. Although it takes a little public transportation savvy to reach this church it was so worth the effort, and to be honest, it wasn't difficult at all. Just reveiw the ATAC website to find which bus route goes there.I had been to the other 3 Vatican basilicas in Rome and the only one I was lacking was St. Paul's Outside the walls and I'm so glad I went there. The grounds are just lovely and the interior is beautiful.

Very beautiful and enjoyable with no mob. This cathedral was one subway stop (San Paolo) from our hotel subway stop (Marconi) so we went there immediately after we checked into our hotel. It was indeed very beautiful just as in the multimedia video at: http://www.vatican.va/various/basiliche/san_paolo/vr_tour/index-en.html, minus the brightness as the cathedral was lit minimally (as with all the churches in the rest of Italy). There was no crowd at all and we really enjoyed the peace and quiet. Impressive courtyard too. It's south of Rome center so it might be a good day trip to combine to go to Ostia Antica (great alternative to the Pompeii ruins) and the Lido (switch trains at the Pyramide stop), both worthwhile to visit and away from the dirty and crowded Rome center. Buy a one-day public transport ticket (6 Euros, good deal if you need to ride more than 4 times) will get you to and back to all those places if you don't have a Roma pass.

Simple yet majestic. The whole place was very large with a big, lovely garden fronting it. A huge statue of St. Paul stood in front of the basilica. What's most impressive was the interior which was free of all furniture, yet created a majestic aura. .We went to venerate St. Paul's tomb and offered to him our prayer intentions. A lot of other pilgrims were there too.On the right side of this basilica was a tall closed door which our tour leader introduced to us as 'The Holy Door'. All of us queued to take a memorable photo here.Indeed, a must-visit-basilica.

Easy to Find and a Great Example of the Basilica Style. Take the Metro to the San Paolo stop and walk to the left out of the station. The church is across the road to the left. It's difficult to miss because it's huge. Although there are often a lot of tour groups, I find the church quiet and pleasant. It's the most sumptuous example of a true Roman basilica that you'll find in Rome. (The basilica form was developed and used by the ancient Romans and adapted for Christian churches beginning in the 4th century.) The interior is magnificent. Of the many highlights: the portraits of all the popes up through Benedict; the tomb of St. Paul; the grand floor; segment of the chains that were used to detain Paul; the mosaics; and the huge candlestick. I enjoy the pleasant courtyard in front of the church.Food is available as are restrooms.

Awesome!. We are so glad that our tour facilitator - the Best Italian Vacations, headed by Mr. Alex Lavagnini - brought us here. The place is so huge!! It was also almost filled with fellow Filipinos who attended the first Holy Mass celebrated by our new Cardinal, His Excellency Chito Tagle.

Tips for Travelers in Sacred Places. I accessed this site by catching the Metro; getting off at the Basilica S. Paolo stop which is on the Blue Line in the direction of EUR from Termini. On walking there I approached the building from the side; not recognising it at first until I spotted the familiar facade (see the photos attached). I was in Rome in the off season period which; in my mind is the best time as opportunities for photography are increased due to the fact that the crowds are not there. What I wish to advise people on is how you should approach photography in sacred places. Although I do take a lot of pictures; I am always very aware of remembering and respecting these sites. Once inside; if photography is permitted; I NEVER use the flash to maintain respect for the site regardless of the lighting. I find that the natural lighting in any case gives a nicer picture in most circumstances and in places that are dark; I accept the fact that the pictures will be dark. Not using the flash I feel is the most important way of respecting these places. Also; you should never take photos when Mass in process. I have been to Mass and have seen tourists snapping away with no regard to what is going on. I hope you find this tip helpful; and please enjoy my photos.

Magnificent. This place is magnificent. Coming from the metro, the edifice is not so great, but once you get inside, you will be awestruck by the majesty of this place. Great place to offer prayers and meditate. Exiting on the other side, it will reveal the majestic side of the church.
Wow. The second largest church in the world, all I can say is if you are in Rome visit this basilica. You will not be disappointed.

Beautiful Church. Approaching this church from the metro station it didn't look very special.But once we went into the church and saw the cloisters outside we were very impressed. Worth the train journey from the centre of Rome.

Worth the Hike. This out of the way papal basilica is located in a quiet part of Rome. The walk from historic Rome takes one from quite a mixture of industrial, commercial and residential neighborhoods.We approached the basilica from its more austere side, from the park. Entering around the side, one comes into a tranquil garden courtyard and a fresco of key biblical figures.The interior of the church from the ceiling down to the inlaid marble floors are spectacular.
St Paul Outside the Walls. A beautiful church! One of the largest in Rome (although smaller than St Peters). Took subway to this church.

Spectacular church off the beaten path. We visited here on a "quick and dirty" day tour of Rome. No reservations needed. Beautiful church with some interesting portraits of all the Popes plus a very nice cloister garden area. Worth the time to visit.
Very English. Less Italian ornate, more English in an Italian bender. Very nice and serene to poke into for a quick visit. Unique that it is Anglican
Wonderful. Well worth the journey out from the centre by metro. Huge and beautiful building, not busy with tourists and with excellent cafe and gift shop.
excellent. we passed a nice day with my family. is one pf the best basilica of rome. amazing!!! and guys could play in the big parck just in front. decoration are magnificcent!!

One if the many great cathedrals in Rome. Only downside is that the Cathedral hopping became a bit boring as they all were so similar. Think its best to save visits here to religious observances only.
St. Paul Outside the Walls. Loved it! Away from the center, not so crowded but very beautiful place worth to see! Outside mosaic but also inside the basilica are absolutely amazing!

My favorite. While St Peter's Basillica is more well known, St. Paul outside the Walls was my favorite, a gem that not the typical tourist would go to see. Overwhelming beautiful and spiritual. My viewpoint may be slanted towards St. Paul as I was on a "journey of Paul" tour. Still, it is 2nd only to St. Peter in size and just as incredible.
St. John. Although St. Paul's is not walking distance from central Rome, this place is well worth the trip. Loved it! Do not however, pay for the extra tour, it was disappointing.
St. Paul Outside the Walls. We went to see the apse mosaics that survived the 1823 fire that destroyed the basilica. They are so beautiful that they gave me chills.

Worth the trip. After seeing countless beautiful churches in Rome, I wasn't quite sure about one more that was a cab ride away from the city center. It was breathtaking! Its sheer size is incredible, and everywhere you look there is something amazing to see. It was Sunday morning and there were services going on, but it wasn't crowded at all. We did not pay to go into the cloister or ancient museum.
Sore feet. Great seeing all the ruins coming alive again with the work getting done.Only negative was my sore feet after allthe walking!

a must see in Rome. Not so famous church in Rome, but really worth visiting. Splendid architecture, spacious, rare and marvelous windows made in alabaster, astonishing colonnades made of marble, beautiful garden. what makes this church breathtaking is the history 'pictured' to perfection, surrounded by all its glory in gold. Take a good camera, with you to capture some really good shots.We really enjoyed visiting this church.
worth to see. worth to travel by metro to see it. One of the four major basilicas in Rome. Must see al of them - St. Peter, St. Paul, St. John Lateran, Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore.

Sheer Beauty just outside of Rome. We rented E-bikes for the day, and except for a couple of crazy intersections, this Basilica was not hard to reach and definitely worth the commute!The gardens and porticos are beautiful, the architecture sublime. When you visit, definitely pay the extra price to go into the Cloister. It was the best part. Also, I recommend renting the translation devices for a guided tour. Even not understanding Catholicism, seeing this Basilica gave me a deep appreciation of the faith. This Basilica holds what appear to be the remains of the Apostle Paul, which was humbling. The art and marble work was genuinely inspiring.

Stunning and awe inspiring. Noted many comments that this was not too busy and so it proved. If you approach by the side from the metro make sure you see the front courtyard with the impressive statue of St Paul. The inside - third biggest church in world according to Lonely Planet is just amazing. The cloisters are five euros but spend the money as they plus the exhibition and the underground area are very interesting and after all you've paid nothing to get in . While you are at it have a coffee and cake at the cafe
Worth the visit.. The cathedral is bit outside the major cites of Rome but it is worth the visit. It is easy to reach by metro. I liked the cathedral's historical and religious significance.

Away from the main tourist items, but sooooo worth it. This is one of the four major basilicas in Rome, and simply breathtaking. If your time is limited, take the Metro (catch Red Ottaviano just a few blocks north of the Vatican to Termini, then transfer to Blue to Basillica San Paolo). Cost is a few Euros - believe me its worth it. From the Metro stop, you will approach the basilica from the rear, might not be obvious but its about a block up and a block over, just past the street vendors. Decent café on premise to grab a quick sip / bite.

Not to be missed. Incredible, a must see. Stunning and takes your breath away. We were on tour so we were taken there so can't comment on how hard or easy is is to get to. Free admittance and so worthwhile.
Impressive church. A really big church with impressive ceiling. A shame the outside is surrounded by gauntrees. Very reachable by Metro (one way ticket 1,5euros). Free acces

Well worth the short train ride.. The Basillica is easy to reach Metro line B, just a few stops down from Termini, get off at Basillica S Paolo, then a 5-10 minute walk past the Hospital and you are greeted by a quite stunning building. Yet more incredible architecture, interior is quite beautiful, so detailed, not crowded and free entry, a must see in this City.
One of the four major basilicas. St. Paul's Outside the Walls may sound difficult to reach from the city center, but it is readily accessible by the Metro and is certainly worth the trip.

Very interesting. I finally understand the sequence of Popes. Be sure to see more recent in second row in alcove below the top row of Pope pictures.
Beautiful grounds and so impressive. Worth the time spent getting there to San Paulo Metro stop.
Stunning. Our tour guide got us here before the crowds and it was very beautiful. We were in awe of the architecture and the decorative walls,etc.

Must see!!. A little out of the way, but easy to get to via the metro. This church was one of our top three favorites on our entire Italy trip! Walking into St. Paul’s was magnificent! The grand hall is gorgeous! Beautiful everywhere you looked. I wish I could paint you a true picture of this basilica. From the moment we entered there was someone playing the organ. Soft, sweet, melodious strains of music wafted around you as you walked through the church taking in the beauty. We ended up being here still at 5pm as mass began which was absolutely gorgeous.This church was built over the place where early Christians believed the Apostle Paul to be buried. When archaeologists dug underneath the church they found this sarcophagus which had the remains of a man who would have died around the same time as Paul and inscriptions on the outside saying “This is Paul” meaning that there is a chance this really was the burial place of the Apostle Paul. Either way, the church is beautiful.
The best place in Rome. I think it was the most stunning church in Rome. The atmosphere and the outside architecture was just breath taking. For sure, will be visiting this church again.
Beautifully rebuilt church. I didn't think I wanted to see this but our Rome in a Limo guide brought us here. Pretty amazing. All 273 popes on the walls.

Best church. This was an amazing surprise, as it's not in any guide books or traditional tours, but it really is a beautiful church. The area might put you off a bit, but the interior is grandiose, while the best part is the inner courtyard, where, on a sunny day, you can find a really nice place to relax.

Outside but possibly the best. When we visited St Pauls it was a beautiful sunny day and our first impression was WOW. The whole place was magnificent inside and out and unlike many churches in Rome it still felt like a church, not a gallery.
worth a few extra stops on the train. Just amazing to be there and see the tomb and chains of St Paul... I have been there before but I couldn't resist going back.
Must visit. Just beautiful.. A little far from local attractions but B line subway takes you right to it! The Church was unbelievable, a blessing to have seen where St. Paul is laid to rest.
St Paul's. Pretty long trip on the train. Very empty. Skip this if you are presses for time. Easy to see St Paul relics.

As important as St. Peters. I visited many churches during my trip to Rome and this church was the most impressive. The architecture, the statues, the artwork. It was astounding. It is a little off the beaten track but worth every moment.
Lovely. Lovely quiet Church full of history. Enjoyed the visit and the walk through of the excavations. Not hordes of people. Read up on it before you go.
Beautiful site, a must see. We went here for our wedding photos and people were coming up to get photos with us and congratulate us. Very beautiful landmark which I cannot wait to return to.

Calm place with less crowds... The place had a wall on the outer portion and and nice green garden on the inside before entering the church.
it is a place not to be missed.
worth seeing. Worth seeing if you have the time, but not even close to St Peter's (or any major Christian cathedrals, like St Paul's or Notre Dame)

Almost as good as Sait Peters. A bit off the beaten track- have to take metro- but worth it. Easily spend an hour. Not crowded (on Wednesday. Massive - on the outside not suspected to what beauty lies inside.
Don't miss this. Outstandingly spectacular. In some ways as good as St Peters, not so many people but as breathtaking with amazing frescoes and art work. Huge and beautiful garden to wander theough.

Worth going the little bit out of your way. If you are taking a tour of Rome, you will likely pass by this church with the yellow mosaic and wonder if it's as beautiful on the inside. It is, and it's definitely worth going the tiny bit out of your way to see the 5 naves, 80 columns, Cavallini mosaics, altar canopy by Cambio, and perimeter medallions of the popes. Without question, you will be drawn in by the chains which held St. Paul before his death. Imagine him being dragged to this spot outside the walls of the city, bound in those chains, to his beheading.Don't Miss: The bronze Holy Door, which, like the one at St. Peter's Basilica, is only opened during Jubilee years. Note: As you exit on the south side, notice the ruins from the original church prior to the 19th century fire. The cloister pavement is also original.

We almost didn't go!. My husband and I were in Rome with a tour recently and decided to take a tour to the catacombs which included this church as a side excursion. This church ended up being the highlight of the tour since the catacombs were not that cool. I'm really glad we went and got to see it. Every church in Rome, and in Europe is special, but this one was one of the best ones we saw. Our guide told us the story on it and we thought it was super interesting. The church is beautiful inside and outside and the gardens are beautiful too. Not to be missed!

Beautiful and peaceful. This may not be in the main tourist area of Rome but it is fairly easy to get to this cathedral using the train system. The basilica does not have the crowds and stress that you'll find in St. Peter's Basilica, it allows you to enjoy the church more and at your own pace. Just like other churches in Rome it is beautiful inside, lots of things to appreciate. The sarcophagus of St. Paul is worth a moment of quiet contemplation and appreciation in its simplicity. Beautiful chapels inside with lots of information. Definitely worth the trip.

Not to be missed!. St. Pauls Basilica does not get half the credit that it deserves. It has similar art work that you can see at St. Peters with less hustle and bustle. The peace and quiet here is almost mesmorising when looking up at the staue of St. Paul. Inside the church itself is certainly not a let down. Around the top of the walls close to the ceilings are the portraits of all of the Popes - past and present (well, the current Popes' portrait is waiting to be put up). As an added bonus there is an air conditioned gift shop, wash room area and snack shop.
Holy place. paintings of all the Popes surround the ceiling, Easy access to it. Was nice to see security making women cover bare shoulders and short skirts and shorts to be decent and reverent.
The best. This is the best church I saw in Rome apart from St Peter's Basilica. It is worth the trip by metro.

Beautiful and serene. Once inside this building there is a real feeling that you are in a place of worship and somewhere quite peaceful and serene. I actually preferred this to st peters as the thousands of people and the noise of the vatican take something away from what the place should be about. St pauls is not the most impressive outside but inside it is beautiful and well designed. There were not many people there either and this was the middle of the afternoon aswell, probably because of its location outside the main tourist areas. Not sure about transport out there because we decided to walk for the excercise!!overall a must visit and worth the effort to get to

A very wonderfull expierience. This was the surprise of the tour tot Rome. You must do yourself a favor to visit this church. It was way a better experience than the St Peters Basilica. There was not to many people. The grave of Paul is told to be there, and it was a more silent presence.

Wonderful Tour. My wife and I saw this as part of the "Major Basilicas & Holy Stairs" tour. It was one of the best tours we have had. Our tour was on 9/16 at 2:00 pm. Before the tour we were hesitant on wither it was right for us. It was very hot that day and after walking around the Vatican our feet were tired. However, this tour with the guide we had is a must do for Rome. We had an amazing time and the guide was full of information for all areas including the history, legends, and rumors. He mentioned he was a history history major, however I am not good with names. I wish I was able to remember so we could thank him by name. The tour was of three churches by bus.
Fantastic. If you miss this you may as well not go to Rome. This was fantastic and religion doesn't have any thing to do with it. It's was fantastic.

Very worth finding!. This sight was one of our favorites, but was a little hard to find. It's on the blue Metro line, which we accessed from the Colosseum (take the San Paulo stop and the Church is across the street). High recommend!
Beautiful Church and Experience. It was a great experience, the church is very beautiful and since you enter it is very impact, all the details, it has to be add to your visit list.
Brilliant discovery. This may not be so "In your face" as St Peters basilica, but was far more elegant and awe inspiring....certainly worth a visit

Amost as good as St Peter's. what a wonderful church. If you are a catholic (or a believer for that matter) please do not miss going there. The church itself is sooo beautiful, so serene. We took the time to sit and pray there and it was a very moving experience. My husband and I didn't want to leave, I could have easily spend half the day there. Go on a weekday so it's much calmer.
day at st.paul. went on a Sunday........ WAY to crowded, couldn't even move most of the time, beautiful though, but go on a WEEKDAY !

Amazing and worth the extra effort to see. This church is just so beautiful and quite different to the majority of churches in Rome. There were not a lot of tourists visiting, which was a nice change from most of the other major sites in Rome. We chose to take the bus from our accom in Campo de Fiori. Unless you are sure of the bus route I would not chose this option. On the website for the church is said to catch bus 23, which we did. What we didn't know was that we caught the bus going the wrong way, so we had to go to the end of the line and then change buses. We got there eventually but it took a long time! It was however worth it.
wow. wow wow wow really reccommend to every one, must see ones in life, no many words to describe how beautiful this place it really is

Magnificent. This church is huge and magnificent. The entrance is unusual with a garden enclosed in columns. The mosaics on both the exterior and the interior are unique. It's on the outskirts of Rome but at the same time easily reachable by metro.
wonderful!. Not so famous cos a bit out of the center and other sightseeing points but really deserve the effort!! just go!...

Worth the trip. I actually appreciated this basilica better than the crowded St. Peter's basilica which may be unbelievable to some but bear with me, there were several reasons I liked this church. It's outside the center of rome and you can take the Metro B line. We bought the 3 day tourist pass for the Rome public transportation which cost us about 16 euros each for adults, children are free yeah! but it was worth it. We just basically hopped on bus, the metro and planning where to go was easy. The Metro system was easy to understand. We went on a weekday around 1pm and it was so quiet, serene and solemn. Which how it should be coz I think people tend to forget that this is a church and a place of worship. There were probably less than 20 people inside this huge basilica and they allow you to take pictures even with flash, the one thing they were strict about was the attire. Knees and shoulders should be covered, but wearing a scarf around the waist and over the shoulders is acceptable.I was blown away by the art, the ceiling, my mouth dropped open when I walked in and it took a while for it to close. Thankfully there was no flies around. After walking around a bit, if you are catholic you can go down this set of stairs in the middle where the crypt of St. Paul is said to be in...but you cannot see the crypt, just a metal grate and say a little prayer too. There is also a small table by the stairs where one can write down prayer requests for mass with donation. We did not go to the archeological site because you have to pay 5euros so went to the gift shop instead. It's a big shop, airconditioned and has a lot of variety for souvenirs and gifts.

Beautiful Basilica in Rome. The Church is well preserved and beautiful. The statue of St. Paul in the courtyard is especially touching. The inside is airy and fresh..beautiful carvings on the ceiling. The portraits of the past Popes go all the way around the worship area and that was really interesting. Good place to visit along with the Vatican.

Beautiful Basilica. The St. Paul's was not on our list of "must see." But we booked a private tour with the guide Gigi Zavaglia and she insisted that we see it because it's one of the most beautiful churches in Rome. We were glad she brought us there. It's certainly in much better condition than other churches we saw, having only been recently restored. In fact it seems almost a little too new. Since it's not so close to the other attractions, there are much few visitors here and you can enjoy the arts and beauty of the church in peace and quiet.
Beautiful Church. Amazing art, windows, building, etc. Its incredible to see all the detail in this church. Worth going out of your way to see.

St Paul Outside the Walls. This was very interesting. All of rome is very interesting and you must see and do it all if you can to understand the history. You can find all of need when you google Rome and You can pick and choose what interest you based on the time you have. See it all if you can.

Worth the hassel and effort !. Beautiful Basilica, a hassel to fight the crowded "Linea B: light rail. Keep you hand in you pocket to keep out pickpockets. Short walk from the light rain to the Basilica.. Once inside all my concerns with the outside world disappeared....so peacefu and serene. We were there about 3:00PM on a weekday with hardly anyone else. Reading of St. Paul's life it was lmind boggleing actually being THERE and feeling the peace and beauty of the entire area. Your camera is a must. Don't forget to keep your hand over your purses and wallets....we lost a wallet and credit cards on this visit to Rome. .
Another lovely church. This is worth a visit and can be reached easily by bus or train from the city. Not many people so was calm and pleasant change from the busy city.

Get their Early to Avoid Line-ups. The only thing I didn't like is the fact that you were herded through like animals. One of my friends was so emotional about being in the chapel that I told her to stay and sit and take it all in if that was what she needed. She thanked me for that it was just what she needed. Very much an experience that everyone needs to experience.
Worth the Trip!. It is free to visit this massive basilica! It was one of the most impressive we saw while in Rome. The tomb was very interesting as well.

Simple, free and less crowded than St. Peter's. Nice basilica. Less glitter than St. Peter's but feels more serene inside. You can see St. Paul's sarchopagus. Easily accesible on Linea B. Nice garden and gift shop. Benedictine liquers are good. A must to visit.
Amazing!. Amazing building. Absolutely stunning and breathtaking. Loved it. Definitely a must-visit in Rome. Probably one of the most impressive things I've seen.

Impressive. Very historical, able to take good photographs. Very exciting and atmospheric. A bit of a walk round to the Cistine chapel but well worth it. Lovely tourist shops, not too expensive. Marvellous Sculptures inside, etc The Pieta.

Impressive. Impressive basilica outside of the center of Rome. Silent, imposing, never ceases to amaze me with its silent grandeur. View of the facade from outside is striking with the brilliance of its colors.
Amazing. One of the most beautiful churces I have ever seen.I've seen it twice and I'd like to go there any time I come back to Rome. It's a truly majestic sight.
St Paul's outside the walls. Beautiful church with magnificent paintings. Well worth a visit and outside there is a small bar to relax with a drink.

Yet another amazing sight. Very impressed, beautiful and stunning.
Not sure why people state that its an issue having to travel or that's its a little out of the way. Walking around the area and stumbling onto places makes Rome one of the most amazing cities that I have been too.

Beautiful & Majestic. We were lucky enough to be renting accommodation in this area so it was on our doorstep. We just strolled along to it one afternoon, not expecting too much. We were in for a surprise. We entered a beautiful, Majestic building, absolutely stunning. To top it off, the monks were chanting in prayer as we strolled around soaking up the atmosphere. We also strolled around the garden at the rear of the building. So beautiful!!! The service in the cafe was wonderful. Very polite & accommodating. A must see. It is free to visit, but you can pay extra to view ruins below Basillica.( I think it was about 5 euros) The metro stop is St. Paolo (B Line) Then a 5 to 10 minute walk to the Basillica. Very easy to reach. We travelled every day from this station to all over Rome. Sometimes changing at (A Line) at Termini.
A peaceful visit. The first church we entered inRome... Beautiful and quiet. One of the four patriarchal churches in Rome. A must see for any visitor.

Beautiful, large church. Sure, it is kind of out of the way but you can easily go on the Metro which leads you straight to here. It's free to enter and it's massive. A good thing about it is that it doesn't seem too popular with tourists and so it feels sort of empty when you come inside. So it's very quiet and peaceful. Make sure you go to the end and walk out so you can see the gardens, it's truly beautiful.
Amazing!. it's a little bit far from the main attractions in Rome but its a must see! we didn't expect it to be such amazing basilica.
Excellent. I liked this church very much. Experience was marvelous. I recommend it to all. St. Paul the Apostle of the Gentiles

Unassuming place of beauty. The beauty of this basilica is quite overwhelming. It is easily reached through line B of the metro (station Basilica S. Paolo - it is around a 10-15 minute walk from here) and is not overrun with tourists, which enables the chance to take things in at your own pace, unlike many other popular sites. The courtyard of the basilica is also beautiful. There is a museum and archaeological site that can be visited as well for an additional charge (in our case 5 euros per adult of the EU, free for our daughter who is under 18). If you have the chance to visit the basilica, do!

great time. Category: Religious Sites; Landmarks/ Points of Interest; Historic Sites; Churches/ Cathedrals Basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls Piazzale di San Paolo, 1 Transport: Metro: Line B (Get off at Basilica San Paolo) Bus: 23 (Pincherle-Parravano – Get off at

Not to be missed. San Paolo fuori le Mura can be reached by Metro Line B (Laurentina) and stop at San Paolo and you will find the Abbazia infront of you. Do visit the museum for an extra €6. If you like chocolate do purchase some from the souvenir shop. This chocolate is done by the priests from the Trappist Monastery outside Rome.

Large, beautiful Basillica - across street from metro. We researched sights in Rome that were unusual - St. Paul Outside the Walls was one on our list. It was easy to get to on the Metro. It is a beautiful Basillica - very large - not many tourists, with lovely mosaics at the altar and in other areas. There are also archealogical ruins to explore for an extra cost. The crypt of St. Paul can be seen below the sanctuary floor in this church. The neighborhood around the church seems to be very quiet. We did not go into the book shop but were told later that the monks serving this parish make chocolate and sell it in the book store.
View all the popes. Majestic building and architecture. Was very crowded. Painted pictures of all popes on display. Large area around the church to relax.

Amazing place. Although it took me a while to reach there, but it is worth it ..You feel out of this universe. A very peaceful beautiful place , bringing you back to old centuries.. You feel that you exist in that time .
Beautiful Basilica!!. This is the second largest Basilica in Rome! If you have time -- visit. It is beautiful and not crowded at all. St Paul's crypt is visible at the altar

One of the best rivals St Peters. The walk towards the entrance is by high iron gates and then you are greeted by a courtyard filled with greenery the mosaics greet you warmly. The church is huge with 5 aisles - the focus on the grave of St Paul and the mosaics is wonderful. The best part it is quiet and peaceful not many people. We were able to sit and observe the art and the liturgical aspects of the basilica. This is our 3rd trip to Rome and the 1st time here - not sure why I waited.

Worth the effort to see it. Especially if seeing the burial site of St Paul will mean something for you. The cloister is also very beautiful and there is an excellent visitor centre which also sells liqueurs and food items which the monks themselves make.

My most favourite visit to date!. St. Pauls Basilica does not get half the credit that it deserves. It has similar art work that you can see at St. Peters with less hustle and bustle. The peace and quiet here is almost mesmorising when looking up at the staue of St. Paul. Inside the church itself is certainly not a let down. Around the top of the walls close to the ceilings are the portraits of all of the Popes - past and present (well, the current Popes' portrait is waiting to be put up). As an added bonus there is an air conditioned gift shop, wash room area and snack shop.

Monumental. As basilicas go, this one definitely stands out. Not only does it contain relics such as the sarcophogus of St. Paul, but many aspects of the buildong are fairly modern due to its burning down a few hundred years ago. The way in which old meets new is interesting, and the money funds poured into the basilica are clear. Off the beaten trail, the site is not too crowded, and better still almost all of it is free of charge.
A Baptistery that tourists forgot.. Wonderful,peaceful,and don't miss the archeological museum. Low tourist area yet some of the most beautiful art. Close to the Metro so very easy to get to.

Very moving. Very engaging placebo visit. The chapel itself where the post that Tradition says Paul was executed on, was very moving to see. The artwork inside is beautiful, including the three side altars that represent the actual execution of Paul. There is a painting representing St. Peter's execution, and an incredible tile mosaic from early Christian days when Christianity was essentially against the law. A very thought-provoking experience. A tour guide, or some research beforehand will enhance the traveler's experience.
worth the trip. Good place to visit.sensational building with out the crowds of st Peters.Worth the cab ride if your not on a bus tour.

Must See. I am a sucker for old churches, and this is one of the nicest. So much history, so many stories, so much art, and so much to see! This place just fills you with awe, so it should definitely be on your "must see" list of attractions in Rome. Being located away from the other tourist attractions also means that there aren't as many tourists. There is a gift shop on the premises where you can get religious articles and also a decent snack bar.
Do take a trip its worth the afternoon out. We both enjoyed our morning here and would reccomend it while in the area. Do mae an effort to see it you wont be dissapointed.

It was not what all the 5 star ratings said. I must be honest, I have covered and seen a great deal of in Rome in the past 5 weeks, and seen many, many beautiful churches, minor basilicas and the four major basilicas (especially a few awesome little churches off the beaten path), but beyond sheer size (and a cool garden), this basilica was not even close to Basilica di Santa Maria Maggiore, Basilica San Giovanni in Laterno and/or St. Peter's Basilica, in that order. Yes, that means at BEST it was number 4 of 4. Plus, it is a ways from downtown, as we walked to it and back from city centro (for the exercise too). The art is okay, the half dome main chapel was 'okay' even with the commissioning pope some how included to the left (facing it) of Jesus' feet, but it just felt completely different than the other three. I do admire the opportunity to actually go into each chapel, and everywhere else but the altar, but it let me down. IMHO this is not a must see, but if you want to fill out the major basilicas during your visit to Rome, please don't say you were not warned this one is not on the same level.

My Favorite Basilica to Visit in Rome. This basilica is my favorite to visit for many reasons. First, it does not draw the huge crowds that St. Peter's does and so with only you and a small number of other people, you get the feeling that you have solitude with your thoughts and feelings. The place is very solemn and a sense of reverence will pervade your whole visit. Second, it is very easy to get to. A quick cab ride or a ride on Metro line B to the St. Paul exit. a five minute walk will put you at one of the entrances. Finally, after our visit we explored the area around the St. Paul stop and found great local places to eat and various shops where we found clothes, purses, jewelry, etc., at way better prices than in the more popular tourist stops.The garden inside the walls (see picture) is beautiful and they also have a cafe and, of course, a souvenir shop. The paintings on the ceilings and the other art was magnificent. I would advise that you take a couple of hours and go experience this outstanding place.

Moving Experience. Of the four papal basilicas, this is my third favorite behind San Giovanni in Laterano and Saint Peter's in terms of architecture and art, but my favorite experentially. For some reason, it doesn't draw big crowds, so you almost feel as if you have the place to yourself. It's dim and reverential, and just feels real. The sarcophagus containing the body of St. Paul was recently rediscovered, not surprisingliy, exactly where it was traditionally believed to be under the main altar, undisturbed since interrment in the 4th century (when Constantine built the original basilica). Before then, from St. Paul's martyrdom in the 1st century, his body was kept in the catacombs on the Appian Way.

A cab ride well worth it. Many visitors to Rome focus on sites that are centrally located. However, if you venture away from the center you will discover a magnificent huge church called St Paul Outside the Walls. It is an amazing structure, with wonderful gardens. The collection of art and the ceiling is unbelievable. I spent over three hours in the church. Everywhere you looked there were new and exciting things to see and absorb. It was like information overload, but in a very positive sense. It is well worth the cab ride to visit one of the four major churches in Rome. It is a must when visiting Rome.

Big Basilica outside the Roman Walls. It is a very big Basilica and less crowded than San Peter's and just few steps away from the Metro B station Basilica San Paolo, with a impressive mosaic at the main altar and a very charming cloister.
No tourists. Went on a hot mid-June day, at lunch time. We were almost the only ones there. No 23 bus gets you there.
Favorite basilica. Of the four major basilicas this is by far my favorite at any time of the day or evening it is breathtaking. The magnificent statue of St. Paul is incredible and a must see.

Quiet in the heart of Roma. A quiet oasis in the heart of Rome, beautiful mosaics, stained glass, and a lovely garden for solitude and reflection. There was an art exhibit inside featuring local artists, very enjoyable .

Big Surprise. This was a last minute visit and I was not disappointed. It was amazing. I walked in the side door to be greeted by this hugh internal area. The ceiling and side columns alone are worth the visit. Also the crype of St Pauls. You will be delighed in this gem of a church.
Private tour with Julia, van and driver. Beautiful Basilica! Incredibly open, lovely outdoor area, and the history of all the doors is fabulous!

Great place to walk around after dinner. It is cooler and the area is beautifully lighten up af night.
It is close to the metro station. There is a wonderful water faucet.Bring a plastic bottle to fill in the pure cold water.
Massive!. Of particular interest to me was the depiction of all the popes portrayed in medallions above the pillars that encircle the whole church. Therefore, don't forget to look up!

Outstanding mosaics. This is considered one of the "Major" churches of Rome (along with Santa Maria Maggiore, St. John Lateran, etc.), but it's seldom visited. That's a shame, it's a beautiful church. The mosaic on the front is world-class.
Also, very nice cafe to relax in after your tour.

Worth the trip!. Beautiful basilica. Amazed by the portraits of the popes. Kind and helpful staff. Really pleasant café in the courtyard.
Not crowded. Huge amounts of space.
ST. PAUL'S. Another magnificent basilica. Huge building with paintings of every pope from the beginning of time. St. Paul's chains on display in the front of the basilica

Breathtaking!. This is a Basilica you wont want to miss! It is so beautifully laid-out that you can immediately sense peace and serenity in the outside gardens as well as upon entering the Church. If you go when the monks are chanting you are in for an added delight! They celebrate Vespers and is it is just transcending!

St Paul. The Papal Basilica of St Paul Outside the Walls, commonly known as St Paul's Outside the Walls, is one of Rome's four ancient major basilicas or papal basilicas. Well worth seeing for St Paul's tomb and history. We found a local neighborhood taverna around the block and took a bus to the Forum.

Peaceful, yet impressive holy place. The basilica of St Paul is far away from most other sites in Rome, however it's only a short walk from the metro station so quite easy to get too.On the walk up to the entrance, you pass either a hospital and stalls selling goods, or open park land that had a fun fair and would be hosting a concert later. If this felt a touch tacky, then as soon as you approach the church all thoughts are focused on the exterior - it is truly amazing.The most striking feature for me was the huge golden wall that was unlike anything I've seen in Rome. When the sun is shining on the wall, it looks dazzling. The entrance garden is very well tended and has a large statue in the centre as you approach the entrance doors.Be aware that as this is a holy place, then you will need to cover up bare skin.Upon going through the main entrance doors, you are in a grand hall that is huge - it reminded me bizarrely of the school hall in Harry Potter. Very grand, very quiet and very impressive.The main altar was very grand, and the tomb of St Paul was also visible, but the most impressive thing was several small chapels off the main hall - private, discreet and personal spaces in which to pray.One of the most impressive churches in Rome and a very peaceful place. Very much a sense of history and culture here.Although free to enter, there were a couple of paid for areas such as the excavations - I didn't try these though so cannot comment. A small store is also on the way outside along with some facilities.Recommend for any visitor to Rome.

Wondrous. In some ways, I think many of the churches in Rome are interchangeable to the extent that you could see any of them during your visit and not be sorry. Any of them could leave you speechless. That said, I would hate for anyone to miss the Papal Basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls. With its huge colonnaded courtyard and palm trees, it's unlike any other church in Rome. It is peaceful and elegant both inside and out. The translucent alabaster windows are sublime. The Emperor Constantine built the original church on St. Paul’s tomb in the 4th century. The tombstone and one side of the sarcophagus can be viewed near the altar. Standing before it is a profound experience. There was no cost to enter the church and there were only a few people there when we visited. It’s a very special place and comes highly recommended.
Be patient, the line moves fast. The line wrapped completely through one side of the square, but only took 20 minutes including security screening.

Stunning church - a must see!. St. Paul Outside the Walls is a beautiful church that does not attract the large crowds that it should - because it is outside the walls. We took a short ride on the Metro and were there in 20 minutes - and it was well worth the trip. It is simply one of the most beautiful churches we have visited - filled with art and history. We spent 4 hours there and could go back to take in more.
Beautiful church. Well worth a look at the amazing art work throughout the church. Often small concerts take place here, worth a visit!

worth the metro trip. An amazingly large and gorgeous basilica away from the mad throngs of tourists. Gorgeous architecture and easy to get to on the metro. Pretend you are a local and attend a mass. We couldn't understand a word they were saying but there was a lovely choir singing and we were happy to be there.

Amazing mosaic inside. I am not a religious person, I was however impressed by the mosaic inside, made in tiredly of different coloured natural materials that has not deteriorated in colours over the years. Stunning.
Opera. This American Episcopaelean Church has an Opera season during the summer months. We went last night ... it was excellent.
Amazing. If you take the dark Rome full day tour you can see this and all the other Basilicas. This is one of my favorites. Amazing and not crowded even at high season. Well worth the trip

Well worth it!. St. Paul's Basilica is a fantastic and spectacular church. If taking the subway you need to get off at the Basilica di San Paolo stop and walk about 10minutes to the church. When first walking in you will see just how gorgeous it is. Taking a look at the hall with vast amount of columns and there are just no words to describe how beautiful it is. There is also a section where you can pray right by the tomb of St. Paul.

Beautiful, uncrowded church. We went at around 6 pm, and were delighted to see no other tourists in this church - only locals. Main caveat was the outside was under renovation. While I don't rate this church nearly as highly as those in the Vatican, it was still worth the trip entirely. Service began at around 7, which was beautiful to watch.

Worth the trip!. What a beautiful Basilica!. It is not in the city center but it is very easy to get to on the metro. Well worth the trip. You won"t find the crowds there. The courtyard is so peaceful and beautiful.
History. If you love history n culture the churches history, workmanship, designs, tour guides just overwhelm you with what is out there to see.

Book your tickets on line to avoid LONG lineups. Make sure you have enough time in your schedule for the entire tour. There is about an hour just to get organized and get inside even before the tour starts. We had scheduled a 4 1/2 tour and had to leave just as we reached the Basilica because we had to catch a train to Bologna.

Incredibly Beautiful and Much Less Crowded. We loved our visit to St. Paul's for several reasons...first, it is incredibly beautiful (both inside and out). it also has a very open feel inside, relative to many of the other, monumental churches.second, it was very moving to see the tomb of St. Paul and a small section of the chains that he wore.third, we found it to be much less crowded -- which made it a much more enjoyable experience. We went during the afternoon and it was almost empty, relative to a number of other churches we visited (especially vs. the incredible crowds and waiting lines at St. Peter's, it was a welcome change of pace).fourth, it is located next to a large, attractive park. So a good place to take a walk, or have a break, before or after your visit. It would, for instance, be a good place for a picnic before or after.A couple of notes...first, remember that when visiting Italian churches, you need to be wearing either pants or capri pants (below the knee) -- no shorts -- and have your shoulders covered. They were selling (for 1 or 2 Euro's), some simple smocks for the ladies who arrived inappropriately attired.second, although the church is away from some of the centrally located sites, it is close to one of the metro line stops. You can't see the church from the metro exit, however. So we asked a vendor at a newspaper stand and he pointed us in the right direction.
Great Church. Took a cab from the Spanish Steps. Prob payed 12-15 euro because it is not walkable from the city center. Beautiful church. If this is a must if you love religious sites.
Can't believe we were in the spot. where Peter and Paul were jailed from the Bible. Our guide, from Dark Rome tours was a wealth of information about the history surrounding this area.
it was a breath taking tour. we went up 320 stairs and the view from thehighest point was worth it, all the soronding was very beutiful.
One of the best after St Pieters. Certainely one of the best after St Pieters, dont forget to visit the klosters it's really wonderfull

Beautiful Rome. I loved the City but the prices in some of the restaurants were far too high, even for tourists - 2 cups of coffee and 2 pastries 37 Euros ! A bowl of french fries 10 Euros !! It won't put me off going again, but look for the backstreets for value.
Beautiful Church. Very beautiful church. I took many beautiful pictures. Beggars outside the grounds made my nervous. Why can't the government have them removed?
Beautiful. Awe-inspiring, this papal basilica is well worth a visit. Lovely cloister too and grand surroundings.

Gorgeous Basilica in Residential Area of Rome. Very impressive basilica with lots of interesting history. They also have a great gift shop with some wonderful handmade soaps for only 3 Euro for a nice little souvenir gift that doesn't take up much room or cost much. The Benedictine monks have a monastery connected to the basilica and you can purchase original Benedictine brandy in the gift shop too. There is also a nice little cafe with light snacks, etc. on the grounds

Beautiful Church. This Basilica is built on the tomb of St. Paul and is the second largest basilica (after St Peter's). Arrive early as the lines do get long and no "skip the line" tours offered. The architecture and artwork are awe inspiring and worth the visit.

St Paul's Basilica. Excellent architecture and artwork is magnificent. Take note that this tour is a walking tour and apart from the bus between hotel and St Pauls, it's not motorised. You have to walk and it can be a long way so wear good shoes. You may also need to queue in the heat. Also remember that you will be entering what is one of the most significant buildings in the Christian world. Please pay respect to this in your choice of attire, this is specially important to ladies who must not expose knees, shoulders etc. One woman in particular on our tour wore the most inappropriate dress and was refused entry.

Beautiful Basilica Beyond Words.. There is something about arriving in a church early in the morning with only a few people around.Our first impression took our breathe away. The beautiful columns and the high decorated ceilings. The original church had a fire so this was rebuilt without expenses in mind.The reason we came here was because of the high rating on trip advisor and we are so glad we did.Can you imagine being the only ones to go down to look and see where St. Paul is buried? To see the chains that surrounded him when he was in prison? To actually feel the peacefulness of being where he is buried?We walked around and looked at each beautiful chapel, each amazing painting. There is also a replica to show what the original church looked like. It must have been wonderful to see.Our sixteen year old grandson said it was his favorite church of all that we saw on our trip through beautiful Italy. Maybe it was because we came so early and we could feel the peaceful silence so I advise you to do that if possible.Take your time because there are treasures to be seen in hidden corners.By the time we left the buses and tours were coming in.We loved this basilica.
