2nd largest church in Rome. St. Paul's remains are under the alter. Gorgeous cathedral, well worth the visit, even though as the name suggests it's away from many most other attractions in Rome.

A Must See for Religious Tourists. Came here on a trip in the Footsteps of St. Paul. Beautiful architecture and grounds. Friendly priests and monks were very helpful for our group and let us use one of their chapels for a short worship service.

Powerful, beautiful basilica. I would add St. Paul Outside the Walls to the list of "must see" places in Rome. It is a massive, beautiful, heavy, historic place -- with round-framed profiles of all the popes in history. We were there when they were tuning the organ, and that process gave us a mere hint of the power of the organ. We would LOVE to be there during a service of some kind. The accoustics are amazing, and the history is rich. We did not have a guide, and I wish I had studied it more thoroughly before we visited. A stunning place! Don't miss it!
enjoyed visit. a must visit,i dont have anything to dislikes, i really enjoyed my trip and love to go back in rome.

Richly Reverent. With the one exception being the "Church of All Nations" in Jerusalem, for me there is no other sanctuary in the world constructed with the richness and reverence of this beautiful basilica. It is more than lovely to look at it inside and out. The architecture, art and imprinted spirituality evoke a hush in one's soul and offer a fine tribute to the great Apostle. Both the tourist and pilgrim will find time well-spent in visiting this stunning and sanctified place.
St. Paul Outside the Walls. We happen to visit during a ordination service. It was wonderful. A must see for St. Paul devotees. Not as crowded as St. Peters but every bit as moving.
AMAZING. As a total non believer and athiest I went here and through the cathederal. This place is amazing and its power and atmophere is amazing. Still a non believer but this place makes you wonder
The art!. Coming here makes you wonder the bright ideas they had 4-5 thousand of years ago. The artworks comes to life and the baroque.

Centre of Peace. This church was a highlight of our trip. Very peaceful and more of a funtioning church than a tourist attraction. Perfect for contemplation and reflection. A must-see if you are on a pilgrimage.

Just wow!. Amazing basilica. Rome is full of wonderful churches and basilicas but this one is beyond amazing,As a religious site which, it seems, did house the remains of St. Paul, it is important to Christians but it goes beyond that. It is such a huge space and so quiet compared with ther major sites in Rome. Difficult to describe the peace and tranquility that exudes from this place - very spiritual. The art is awesome and it is possible to view it at leisure - it should be on more visitors lists as sites to see. It's not difficult to get to and only 1.50 euro subway ticket, good cafe and nice surroundings.

A must visit. This church is an architectural gem that is not highly visited due to its location away from the historic area of Rome. It is easy to get to by the train, 20 minutes from Termini Station. The remains of St Paul are in a crypt there. The beauty, both inside and out provide a peaceful and meaningful experience. The audio guide is helpful.

quiet bliss. we saw this from our walk to the metro from our hotel and it looked a must see.Of course it's not as big or as colourful as St Paul's but still huge with fantastic marble being used everywhere and unusually, the marble patterns are used for the window panes.Because it was less well attended, to me it seemed even more of a religious experience, rather then what felt like a 'cattle market scrum' in St Paul.Outside there are still excavations being carried out in the old orchard, where a modern museum/restaurant has been built on top but with the facility to go under it for viewing.

Art value. Besides its religious value this place has an important art value when you can witness the work of amazing artists. I believe it's the next place to visit after the Vatican City. You will also have the chance to visit the shop where you will find homemade products to purchase. What is the most suitable is that you won't find it crowdy.
Quiet and beautiful!. This church is not as busy as St. Peter's Basilica. Many beautiful mosaics. Off the beaten path so a bit more difficult to reach but worth the effort.

Very different than the other 3 basilicas in Rome.. This one is much less ornate, overall, than the other 3, but stunning, nonetheless. The mosaic apse can be illuminated by the coinbox at front right of the apse. Stunning ceilings and a beautiful baldicchino. Particularly favorite was a holy water font on the far right, depicting a cherub dipping his fingers in the holy water while a fallen angel cringes nearby.Odd place to find a cafeteria, but food was good and affordable. Had lasagna and Coke Light for €12.This site is an easy stop on the regional train line; if you buy a trans pass (1-, 3- or 7-day), take Metro B to Piramide and transfer to Regional train at the Ostiense station next door. Get off at the Basilica S. Poalo stop.
Hidden treasure. Awesome church. Kind of out of the way but so worth it to get away from the center of Rome for the day. Cloisters are not really worth it. The church is where it's at. Magnificent.

Not on many tourist's agenda. This is a gorgeous church that is a must to visit while you are in Rome. Unfortunately, it is a bit off the beaten path and there are no saints buried here...so it is a forgotten gem on most tourists' itineraries. We managed to tour it because it was part of a package that saw us visit all of the major basilicas in Rome and we are so glad we did!

Discover all the Popes of Rome. This Basilica is second to no other (especially St. Peter's) for its layout and magnificance, and its history. It was fascinating to see that they already had the image of the former pope (Ratzinger) who resigned from office "lit up (as the last pope in order) as is customary. It is an amazing experience to look up and be able to see the images of all the popes of Rome!!

Maybe my favourite church of Rome. One of the most beautiful basilica I've ever seen. The gold of the mosaics and the white of the marble, the green of the palms outside and its magnificence.. It must be visited. Definitely.

Great views.. This is a wonderful place just to sit & admire the view. We saw Pope Frances from here on the Sunday morning from his carriage. It was one of the most exciting things of my life. I feel honoured to see the Pope at the Vatican.
A famous church nearby University of Rome III. Just go there, if you are at Roma Tre. It was one of the more visited sites dung the last Jubilee in Rome.

Unexpected pleasure. This church is not on all the tour stops but should be except that would ruin part of its charm. One of the nice things is you can enjoy the grounds and church without a swarm of people. There are no crowds to fight through to see the statues and the church architecture and stained glass. It is larger than I expected.

beautiful place of worship. the builing was beautiful in its blues and whites with gold, there are pictures of every pope there has ever been up around the top of the the wall in the main chapel , only one is lit up and that is the one of the present pope , if its turned off while your there he has just passed over . this is well worth a trip to see , and is a bit quieter than most of the tourist hot spots .
Spectacular. Very lovely place, Even saw the Pope giving morning Mass which was very moving. Queues are so long, so worth getting a tour or pre-booked tickets

Amazing place. Basilica Papale San Paolo Fuori is a wonderful place to visit,it is one of Rome's most important churches and one of the four papal churches along with Saint Peter's Basilica in Vatican City. Visiting it in the afternoon may avoid the tourist crowds. Don't miss the medieval cloister Entry is free of charge and note that it is closed on Sundays.
Rome tour.. When in Rome, to see Vatican is a must especially when you are a catholic and even more if you are an art lover. It was great to see Michael Angelo's masterpiece .
Beautiful Basilica di San Paolo Fuori le Mura. Beautiful Basilica very close to the Metro line b, I was struck by its size and the mosaics and frescoes inside. Very nice also the cloister.

Beautiful, quiet and moving. It's a place where you can almost feel the ghosts of the past. It's also the only place in Rome where a church security guard asked us to leave due to my daughter's shorts. Years ago I would have expected it, but it's unusual today. Anyway, just be aware!

The most beautiful church in Rome. Rome has a lot of churches, but this one - in my opinion - is definitly the most beautiful one with its very nice courtyard, the large statues and the great light within.
So glad we went.... Our tour guide from RomeinLimo suggested we stop at the Basilica and we are so glad we did. It was serene and beautiful.
must see. After Vatican tour same morning we took tree basilica tour . That was great, not so busy like Vatican. We could really enjoy all the art of basilica.

Stunning. This enormous basilica is located way out of town. My wife and I actually walked from the Catacombs a mile or two to the east. It is a great way to kill your feet. I suggest taking a cab or bus. The inside is amazing and the gardens and piazza are all great places to rest. It is so peaceful. You won't regret it. It seemed to be missing some of the "draw" that some of the other major basilicas in Rome had in respects to masterpiece art.

Soberb!. This Basilica is really jaw droping!...And you go in for free! (You may have to stand in line for some time, though... and with that in mind I would avoid going on a sunday).Don't miss it!!P.S.On the right hand side, once you go in, you have the Michael Angelo's Pietá.

Yet another church. One thing about Rome, there is no shortage of churches. This was interesting for its Eastern Orthodox inspired Mosaics, but otherwise just an ornate box with bones in it. I'm not a christian, so there wasn't anything of spiritual value to me, just a building. However, while there a Spanish pilgrimage arrived and it was beautiful and haunting.

Much better than St Peter's. Not crowded and beautiful. This church is accessible and quiet so you can experience it like a church. The most gorgeous stained alabaster and onyx windows I've ever seen. I won't ever go back to St Peter's.

the colonnade is worth the visit. as always, I am shocked by the ignorance of many tourists that rate this beauty as something average. it is absolutely stunning. the facade is unique, as is the colonnade and the inside of the church. It is only a few subway stops from the city center

Worth the journey. As you make your way around Rome to see the 4 papal basilicas, this one may be the farthest to get to, but it's definitely worth the trip. The basilica and grounds are stunning and it is so fascinating to see the tomb of St. Paul. The basilica had a great history, as well, surviving for such a long time until a fire in more recent years. Then the story of the whole world contributing to it being rebuilt. A great, easy trip down metro line B.
Excellent Basilica. This is near to metro. Fantastic Basilica - free to enter but 4 euros to go into cloisters and relic museum - well worth it
Splendid. Excellent work. It is best to take a guide. Needs at least half a day. But very crowded, you get lost :)

Easy subway ride South of Colosseum. This is where St. Paul is entombed, it is South of the Colosseum and there are no large crowds, the Basilica is beautiful. You can see shackles he was held in prison with. About 10 years ago the Pope allowed the removal of a marble slab which confirmed his tomb was indeed there and they left it open and installed a piece of Plexiglas so it is readily visible.

Time well spent.. We were taken to St. Paul's Basilica as one of our first stops of our day in Rome. We are not religious persons but we very much enjoyed it from an historical perspective, surprised at the wonderful written descriptions that have been placed in most of the areas. We were really impressed with the quiet beauty of the church and now are more particularly enjoying the memories of our trip to Rome after spending time at this Basilica.
A Nice Place. I visited this place in the month of April 2013 and it was not as crowded as the other places.thought it was rather peaceful compared to the rest of Rome during tourist season.
Beautiful and Amazing. This Basilica is so beautiful and St. Paul is buried there, so you can visit his tomb. It was our first stop in Rome and it stands out in my mind as a highlight.
A gem. Located outside Rome it is easy to find. Take the metro blue line. It is designated as part of the Vatican and is a rival for St Peters as best church in Rome
Beautiful. This is a beautiful church with the actual body of Apostle Paul. It is located a little out of the main stream of Rome but well worth the visit.
Beautiful. Paul's tomb and chains...Lovely architecture, lots to see and experienced a service going on. Large church with beautiful artwork.

Worth seeing. What can one say when in Rome, everywhere you go in this great city is a wonder to the eyes, history, paintings, sculptures whatever you are looking at it is with wonder. Whatever you do in your life, make sure Rome and its wonderful churches etc are on you bucket list

A MUST SEE to round out a visit to St Peter's. This was built when the OLD S t Peter'was built and in a similar style but bigger than SP1which shows how when megachurch SP2 was built the Church's "edifice complex" was in high gear, perhaps as Miller opines in his excellent history of St Peter's,to humiliate the plainess of the Protestant movement-churches, ceremonies, etc....fewer crowds allow one to appreciate this beautiful place
What can I say?. Beautiful architecture, breath taking and the wonderful art work created by Michael Angelo and Raphael.
A Must See. A very large church with nearly every square inch covered with spectacular art. Was a refreshing place to visit and ponder the faith that inspired so many.
Worth seeing. The second biggest cathedral in Rome. You can use subway to get there. Worth seeing, but definitely not on the top of the list.

An Amazing Basiica. We were very impressed by the Basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls. We took a taxi to the church. The sheer size of the church is impressive. I love the architecture of the courtyard with its statues and columns that are quite beautiful. The floor of the church is also great, and so is the gilded coferred ceiling. The statues and paintings in the church are also wonderful. I enjoyed seeing the courtyard and the archaeological remains around the courtyard. The gift store was the best religious gift store in Rome that we found and we bought many things there for friends.To return to Rome we had to walk about 1 km to find a taxi, but the trip to this church was worth it.

Overwhelming!. One cannot describe the sheer majesty and beauty of the Basilica of St. Paul's, you have to experience it for yourself. It is free however tour operators will try to sell you a tour. Once you go through security, you can enter the basilica. You will be amazed. The statues, the marble, the paintings. Wow! There are a lot of people that go so make sure you get it out of the way early.

It's worth the short trip from Rome. Amazing architecture, art and history, but the real reason to go is to see the Apostle Paul's tomb and some of the chains that held him while he was a prisoner in Rome 2000 years ago. Next to St. Peter's Basilica I believe it's the largest church in/near Rome. You will need to arrange transportation to see it as it is south of Rome about 15 miles. We took a taxi, then for return transportation had to walk a few blocks to find a taxi stand (about 8-10 minutes away). There is also a Metro (subway) stop just as close as the taxi stand which is less costly. While in the area, walk (or find a taxi) to take you to the San Sebastion and San Callisto Catacombs which are within a couple miles distance of St. Paul's. This church should be on your short list of things to see in Rome!

BREATHTAKING!!!. Basilica S. Paolo is the biggest of all 4 the Basilicas, and it's done in a gothic style, which I personally loved!!!It has some wonderful gardens outside, the ones turists can visit are not huge, but pleasant to be seen.It is the one Basilica that is not downtown, but it is very easy to access, as it is situate only 100 m away from the subway stop that has its name : BASILICA S. PAOLO, on the B line. You can get there in 10 minutes the most, from Termini, the main train station.If you happen to visit Rome, do not miss it, even though sadly, it is not on the touristy maps, because of its position.

What a gem, and so much quieter than the other Basilicas. There are no words to describe the beauty of this Papal Basilica. I almost liked it more than St. Peter's. If you are Catholic, do not miss out on the Chapel of the relics. We spent hours in this Basilica and it didn't feel sufficient. It is one place ai can't wait to revisit
Everything is so fine. Comments cant express !!!. Everything is so fine. Comments cant express !!!History etched to perfection from time immemorial is seems.

Beautiful. This gem is quite far from the Vatican and the other main attractions but it’s not something one should miss. Its so beautiful and full of history that I cannot even describe it in words! All the basilicas have something in particular - this one has a garden!! and the chapels and statues that are in this church plus the paintings and arts - it will definitely take your breath away!!!A not to miss!!!

St Pauls. The church is very reverent and what you would expect of an italian church. The people outside asking you to sign forms giving your details are not very welcoming and pester you going in and coming out. I wasn't impressed considering we had visited a number of churches over our weekend. But I assumed that this was just a local church rather than a tourist church.
Best view in Rome. Pay the extra 2 euros to cut out 200 steps as you still have 321 steps to climb! Well worth it though for stunning views.

Like a rare gem!. We had not heard of this church before our visit. We are SO glad our guide brought us here! Stunning beauty and not much of acrid like other places in Rome. The multiple chapels are unique and the atmosphere is quiet and peaceful. A true gem in the crown of Rome!

St Pauls Outside the Walls. Beautiful Church with beautiful surrounding gardens.Not a grand as St Peters,but far more peaceful.The ceilings are magnificant and it is easily reached my Metro(LineB).Lots if statues and a Chapel dedicated to St Stephens.Worth a visit to get away from the crowds.
A must when in Rome.. This is a visit for everyone who goes to Rome, the tomb of St. Paul. Splendid architecture, also the mosaics of all the popes, it's a splendid visit of half a day.

Lucky we got lost!. During our trip to Rome we walked the wrong way off the train and stumbled on the beautiful church. It hadn't been on out itinery, but I an very glad we saw it. Beautiful alters, paintings and best if all the tomb of St. Paul. A must see when visting Rome.

Astonishing church!. Not so famous church in Rome, but really worth visiting. Splendid architecture, spacious, rare and marvelous windows made in alabaster, astonishing colonnades made of marble, beautiful garden. We really enjoyed visiting this church.
A Must See in Rome. Very big cathedral with a lot of mosaics, and also the tomb of St. Paul. Simple to go there by Metro.

Worth the trip!. It can be hard to get here but it well worth the trouble. No crowds and such a beautiful place. We had to make reservations and pay to see St. Peter's tomb but St. Paul's is there for all to see. We found this cathedral to be a more spiritual place than St. Peter's. We had time and the quiet space we were in need of after a week in the city.

Older than St. Peter's and more intimate. This was a beautiful Basillica and we were so happy we made the trip. We've been to St. Peter's (which you have to go to) but you can't take the time to enjoy it when everyone is elbowing you trying to take pictures. This was fairly empty when we were there and we were able to just look and enjoy. It's very large and it's older than St. Peter's. It is a very short walk from the metro and worth the trip. We were able to go see this and make it back to the Pantheon in less than an hour.

Not to be Missed!. This is one of the four major Basilicas of Rome, but isn't visited nearly as often as the other three. It is beautiful and it also contains the tomb of St. Paul. Because it is less visited, it is much more conducive to prayer. The mosaics are beautiful and not to be missed! There is also a nice little bookstore and cafe. It isn't within walking distance, but as one previous reviewer said, it can be easily reached by either the 23 bus or the Metro. It is more than worth the trip! The inside of this Basilica is magnificent. Inside are chains used to bound paul. His burial place is beneath the altar. Outside is a large mable statue of Paul. Third largest basilica in the world has a serene beauty. St Paul Outside the Walls is considered a part of the Vatican in a way I'll confess I still don't understand. I saw it as a favour to my husband, as part of a full day Vatican tour that included four basilicas. And while I never need to see another basilica again, this is the only one I am actually happy I saw. It was originally built by the Emperor Constantine in the 4th Century, right after he legalized Christianity for his mother, Helen. It's allegedly built on the site of the beheading and burial ground of Saul/St Paul, who was a Roman citizen and could elect the way in which he would be killed. (It's relic is the chains St Paul supposedly was wearing at the time of his death) Because it was outside the walls of Rome it was subject to repeated sackings and was finally consumed by fire in 1823. The wooden ceiling (likely lit by a careless workman's cigarette) imploded into the center of the building rather than falling away, which heated the marble structure to the point that most of the columns exploded leaving only one side aisle standing. This led to a reconstruction that has a lovely unity. It also means that the basilica was gifted with some interesting materials including alabaster columns from Egypt and an impressive malachite side alter from Russia. The windows too are highly original as they are all thin slices of rich yellow, brown and cream marble. The golden mosaic apse (which may predate the fire?) is also very beautiful. While this basilica is now quite accessible by public transport, it doesn't seem to attract the hordes and so has a quiet, serene quality that enhances the pleasure of touring it. Of course it's huge size also dilutes any impact that puny human beings would have on the experience. To satisfy the savage beast, however, St Paul's Outside the Walls has the most generous washroom facilities I saw in Italy as well as a moderately air conditioned cafeteria style snack bar that serves hot foods as well as gelato, ice cream based treats and lots of liquid refreshments.

The mosaics of the Popes is also a study in history and I love seeing the current one highlighted each time I go. It gives such a rich link to Peter, the first Pope and is a good visual for a church timeline. The cloisters are well worth the few euro to enter and the relic museum and history given is beautiful. I am impressed with the new set up outside the cloister for the gift shop and historical facts. Very sleek and lends a greater sense of the sacred to the church itself to have these removed slightly. Be sure to view the church at the front entrance from outside as the golden mosaics in the sun are too beautiful to be believed.

A Gem, Off the Beaten Path. While not well known and touted like St. Peter's or other more centrally located shrines in Rome, this Basilica of St. Paul's Outside the Walls is well worth a visit. Not only are the architectural detail and elaborate ceiling embellishments magnificent, the relative isolation from the crowds of tourists affords an opportunity for a more relaxed, intimate visit to this shrine housing the tomb of the Apostle Paul. An adjacent coffee shop offers a relaxing setting for a cappuccino or light snack while overlooking a small, refreshing garden.
Peaceful. wonderful surprise, very few people and well worth the short trip to visit.

Less crowded that St. Peter's yet grandiose. May not be St. Peter's Basilica but this basilica it still grandiose and worth the subway ride to go see it. Much less crowded than St. Peter's, it is supposed to be built on the tomb of St. Paul. His chains are also on display. Marvel at the ceilings and the portraits of every Pope right on the border of the walls and the ceiling.

Where St. Paul rests. Here is the place where Paul was executed and where he was buried and his body rests, finally, in peace!The big statue in front the church shows Paul with the sword that was executed ( the same in the vatican square).The fine work of marble floor.....The big interior talking of heaven....The figures of all Pope and no more space for many others....The GOLD of ceiling in altar....Nice place for Paul, the big apostle, resting in peace !

Amazing to be at the tomb of St Paul. I highly recommend to get a tour guid or a book to inform you of what you are looking at otherwise, the significance decreases. It was quite an impressive sight but then most of Rome is very impressive.

Hidden Jewel. I've been here before but always return...surprises just around the corner. This time, I did more home work. I looked all over for the crucifix that 'came alive'. Jesus spoke tp St. Bridgett From this cross and gave her prayers, centuries ago, that console Him for the 5000+ drops of blood lost during His passion. I had to ask. It was in an unlit chapel. I got a very dim picture. Such a powerful relic should have been better referenced and identified. Otherwise, the church is a 'must see' and is just magnificent! It is a few blocks from the Metro station and there are very few directional signs.pp

Be sure to visit. This is one stop that I always make when I go to Rome. Easy to get to by the Metro, worth the trip. There is a beautiful courtyard in front of the Basilica. The Basilica itself is beautiful.
Very good. I personally find this one of the four major basilicas to be the least inspiring. It always seems to me to be a bit cold and gloomy, but is worth a visit.
Spectacular place. it's an imposing church, where the organ sound it's impressive

An oasis for the soul. Despite its recent reconstruction, the architecture and atmosphere of this Constantinian basilica, as well as its removal from the bustle of the city, makes St. Paul Outside the Walls something of a spiritual retreat, not to mention the undisputed resting place of the Apostle Paul. It is the only major basilica that has not been greatly redesigned since its foundation. Another great feature is the medallions of Popes from St. Peter to Pope Benedict XVI. Outside, the beautiful quad with palm trees and the St. Paul statue is a nice place to ponder the glory and history of Christian Rome.

Simply Beautiful. Not as richly decorated as many of the other big churches, but has some amazing things that make it memorable - its sheer size, portraits of all the Popes from Peter to Benedict XVI encircling the upper part of the church and the the tranquil cloister/garden areas.
superb. Well worth the time and effort to go and see this. No much effort though as it is within a few minutes of the metro. What a great site when you enter the building you will gasp!
Highlight of Rome Visit.. Went to St Paul's on a guided tour. One of the more memorable sights  of our Roman vacation.
personally i prefer it to the vatican. its a metro ride and bus ride away but well worth a visit, the artwork and peacefulness completely opposite from the vatican

stunning basilica. Absolutely loved this basilica, one of the most beautiful I have seen, well worth a visit. Didn't think the price for the cloisters was worth it though, but overall a magical experience.
Bleesed by the Pope. A beautiful and intimate type of 'square' because of the columns encassing it. I would happily have spent all day just looking around.
Quite good. Certainly big and certainly good history but the renovations have left it with a touristy rather than antiquity feel
Worth the effort. This is a little out of the way but well worth the visit, see if you can have a chat with one of the residential monks who'll let you in on a few secrets.
VERY Crowded. It was VERY crowded with groups and noisy school children. make sure you go early in the morning for the best chance of a quiet time

one of the most beautiful churches ever seen. you have to see the whole church plus the gardens outside it. It is a little bit far from the city center but well worth the travel (just one subway ride away plus a few minutes walk)

had my lunch. After I finished with my tour I had lunch on the steps out side of the basilica, the most breath taking sculptures on the roof if the Basilica, and the fountains you could ponder all day about life. just to cool.
A Gem in the 5 Basilicas of Rome !!!!. Do not miss this ,get a tour of it or do it on your own but go see this quiet gem and you will feel St Paul there

Best Kept Secret. This is a secret place in Rome that few tourists get too. Sad, because it is incredible. Paul with a sword? Check. Alabaster windows? Check? Giant candelabra? O, yes. Go on a sunny day and stand in the sunbeams.
EXCELLENT. St. Pauls - inside out outside is a real treat. There is something to see around every corner
Great. one of the best sights in Rome, worthwhile trip whilst travelling
My favorite Vatican site. I love St. Paul's. It is the best Basilica of all the Vatican Properties. To be there on Good Friday was in and of itself a spiritual event.

New and old. This church is quite impressive. However as it was partly rebuild in the 19thC you are always wavering between admiration and scepsis (is "real" old stuff more beautiful than "new" old stuff...).

Awesome Experience!!!!. Of all the churches I have ever visited, Vatican included, I truly felt that I was in the presence of a higher being in this place. The church is beautifully adorned with paintings and statues. And seeing St. Paul's sarcophagus moved me. And the Monks singing added a special feeling. This is a must see for anyone planning a trip to Rome.It is easily accessible at the Basilica S. Paulo metro stop on the B line.
Big and impressive but go only if you have spare time. Huge and splendid like all the basilicas in Rome. Nice to see but not a requirement.

Beautiful Basilica!. We were there in the late afternoon after exploring other areas of the city. A choir of monks were singing Gregorian chants which added to the feeling of being inside this basilica. There was nothing to dislike! The mosaics were beautiful

A must see. I must admit, I had looked at so many old churches on my previous trip to France, and this one to Italy, that I nearly gave this a miss. What a mistake that would have been. If there you only want to see one church in Europe, make this the one.

Don't miss this beautiful Basilica. we loved the mosaics of the popes, the confessor waiting for penitents, the bookshop and the beauty of the church. With more time would have loved to attend Mass here.
Majestic. Nice to just take in the greatness of it all - liked the grandeur

Stunning. Again, this is an easy subway ride and short walk. This is a huge church with the relic's of St. Paul easily accessible to the public. No long lines, no hordes of people just unspoiled beauty. Really neat portraits of the popes.

Overwhelmed.... ...with the history around me. I've seen so many telecasts, etc. from here and now I was standing in the middle of it. Bustling with tourists and activities - the Vatican was preparing for Holy Week. Beautiful sunny day in a place I will never forget!

If you visit Roman churches don't miss this one. This is a huge basilica complex with the tomb of the Apostle Paul and is actually part of the Vatican. The original church built by Emperor Constantine in 385 burnt in 1823, but columns and other architectural items from the old church are on display, such as a large 12th century candlestick used at Easter. Beautiful cloister garden and really nice bathrooms.
Massive church,worth the short trip. I loved the open space and the overall feeling I got when I walked inside the church. It was a good experience.

St. Paul is out of the way, but a beautiful church. We hopped the metro (blue line) to the Saint Paul stop. We weren't sure where to go when we got to the stop, but consulted a map and went out the left exit. You go up a hill with many vendors right there. There is a ton of graffiti everywhere in the area, so it's a little daunting, but you can see the church from the intersection at the top of the little hill. Go right and it is an easy walk. We were struck by the beauty of this, and all of the churches in Rome. The ceiling is incredible- even more so when you pay and light it up. You can go down and see part of the crypt of Saint Paul. The pictures of the Popes line the walls. It was impressive to see the succession through the building. The little chapels were all worth looking into, also.Outside, near the gift shop, there are restrooms where you can leave a small tip. The shop itself has everything from religious items, to candy, to liquor made by the monks.When we left the gift shop, we came up on the garden area, and the view of the painted mural or mosaic top of the church. It was beautiful. There is also a Jubilee Year door dedicated by JP II off the courtyard.This was a little off the beaten path, but worth the metro ticket to come and see. We were glad that we took the time to do it.
Huge. A lot newer than most churches in Rome, St Pauls was destroyed by fire in the 1800,s and rebuilt. It is still a remarkable church though and I thought it was worth the Metro ride out to see it.
An Unknown Gem. This is the least crowded Basilica in Rome, so if you are in the mood to avoid the crowds, check this place out. It has medallions of each Pope on the inner walls.

go see this one. we were asked to go with a tour guide but having not jumped at the chance he lowerd his price by 20 euro maria was the guide she was brilliant and made it come to life glad we didnt que as you go straight in with a guide and we would not have found it as interesting watch out for pickpockets
Absolutely beautiful. This is a wonderful stop prior to the Vatican. Our driver took us to St. Paul first and the history is amazing. Visit this Basilica and enjoy the quiet serene setting.
Loved it. Gorgeous and a definate must see whilst in rome.it is something we were not expecting to pay much attention to but it really made an impact

Impressive. The official grave of St. Paul is also a papal Basilica. It has recently been renovated so that you can enjoy fantastic wall paintings (including the portraits of all popes). Make sure you visit the fantastic cloister (which is similar in style to the one in the Lateran basilica) and don't miss the golden outside wall of the entry of the basilica.
Another must see. This is one of the four Vatican churches and has to be seen to be appreciated. Dates back to Constantine.
wonderfull. we were very lukey to be able to also see the inside of this besillicaas well as the outside loved the art work ,and the gift shop was very good
Church. We were lucky met ArchBishop of Canterbury on our visit. Very friendly people

The grandeur, the perfect design. Awe-inspiring architecture.
Hated the crowds and long-lines. Rome was the most crowded it had been in 40 years according to the news.

Disappointing..... It's painful for me to give a church 2 stars, especially a Papal Basilica. I made a point of visiting as this is one of the 4 "major" pilgrimage basilicas and I was a pilgrim.Unless you have a great devotion to S. Paul, don't waste your time. The original basilica burnt down in the 1800's and was reconstructed. It's an empty shell for the most part and has little inside to see or experience. You can see a sliver of the apostles tomb below the altar though. In addition, it's a good way outside Rome proper so be sure the Metro isn't on strike or you'll be paying rather expensive cab fares (as I did). There isn't a good bus link and there's no taxi stand anywhere near. If the metro is running, there is a stop about 1/2mi. from the exit.The reason this church gets two stars is the lovely gardens out front and the very nice gift shop selling abbey made products (vs the same tourist postcards at other churches). My major rub with this Basilica is that it felt actively unfriendly to the pilgrim or visitor. It's a cold space to start with, and the people staffing it were just plain mean. One verger gave me directions to a taxi stand...except in the exact opposite direction (even pointed it out on my map!) Another, when asked where the Metro stop was replied "outside the church". Really? Because I was looking for the turnstiles next to the altar....thank goodness you were here to tell me otherwise. I hate to sound petty where a church is concerned but let's face it, WWJD? He wouldn't be jerky to people visiting His house, that's for sure.
Breathtaking. The Mural on the outside is amazing, the chapels are unbelievable. So very glad I visited.

In harmony. A fantastic basilica where i found peace and harmony. Not like St Peters and the Vatican which was much too big and complete the opposite of this feeling.Dont forgot the museum and the inner garden.
roman basilica. this church is as close to a roman basilica as you'll find in rome. it's like walking into the forum 2000 years ago.
Very Beautiful. We enjoyed this stop. Here as everywhere else we could have spent much more time to learn about it's history.
Very nice historical religious site.. This is one of the four basilicas in Rome. It is the home of St. Paul, where is also entoumbed. The gardens there are beautiful.

splendid huge basilica. This church is enormous. We saw a marvelous performance of the Verdi Requiem here with the Vienna Philharmonic and four fabulous Italian soloists. The acoustics are not great for this sort of thing because the sound has far too much space and too many huge marble pillars to bounce around in, but it was quite a spectacle just the same.

Splendid architecture.. You might see San Paolo's from your car as you drive to and from Fiumicino airport. The architectural gem which is the cathedral is presented from an astonishing walled courtyard.The Catholic Church's tribunal (the Sacra Rota) resides there.

A real sleeper great reflection. Enjoyed getting away from central Roma and seeing this stunning Basilica, with St Paul's remains. Quiet, stunning and loads of time and places for personal prayer and reflection.
Ou of town delight. Although extensively rebuilt this is a beautiful and tranquil place to visit.
Wow. Best to read a little bit about the paintings and statues to appreciate their importance

Paul's Chain and Grave-Nothing Better in Rome. This is a must see when in Rome. The Cathedral is HUGE and the artwork is amazing. Part of the Duomo is painted with seemingly gold paint and when the lights are turned on, there is an incredible glow to the artwork. The size of the statues and building is amazing. Also, because it is so far out of the city center, it is not a heavy tourist spot. Go in the morning to the St. Paulo Metro stop, head north and you can't miss it.
St. Paul Beyond the Walls. Outstanding Basilica. The new souvenier shop is very nice. The Basilica itself is quite imposing.
fantastice. i could visit this place again and again, a long que but it soon goes down, the entry is free. there is now where else in the world like it .

the best church I've ever seen. This was the biggest catholic church before St. Paul's Cathedral was built in the Vatican. We were impressed by its gardens, immense size and construction art. Especially impressive are all the Popes represented on the walls as well as the story which says when there will not be any more room for them, the end of the world is near. A definite must-see.
Very beautiful in the evening. It's best to visit this place just before sunset because the mosaics of the gable are best in that lighting
Interesting. Interesting to walk around, bit to commercial in the area for my liking
Individual opinion required.. Enjoyed seeing St Pauls square, but perhaps not as special as I imagined. A nice quick visit prior to the Vatican though.

Beautiful. This was one of the most beautiful smaller churches in Rome. It is not as large as St. Peter's or the others, but the frescos are beautiful and the architecture interesting. I think I enjoyed this the most.
Awesome. Must see for Catholic Pilgrims - tomb of St. Paul.
Amazing!. what a stellar view and art filled chuch is astounding

Another Church. St. Paul outside the walls was just another church to me. With so many other churches to see, I am not sure I would go back here. It has a really nice gift shop, so not a totally wasted trip.

Amazing. It's a must see!!! No wish to minimize the greatness of San Pietro Basilica, but in comparison with it, San Paolo Fuori le Mura is simply more overwhelming! Just do not miss it! It's a little bit far from the city center, but just take the metro till San Paolo Basilica station, line B (blue line), from Termini or Colosseo.
Gorgeous architecture. Another of the four basilicas with a holy door, and not to be missed.
Beautiful. This is an outstanding of a REALLY old-style basillica like the original St. Peter's. It has been well cared for and is really worth the trip.

Unforgettable. Make sure you don't miss this. I have seen it many times in TV but you can't compare the feeling when you actually stand there and try to understand how a man could build it and how beautiful it is.

well worth the trip out for this Basilica. Went on a tour that included this basilica. The tour guide that we had was really good very informative discussing how this church burnt down and rebuilt in the same image. This has one of the four doors that you touch in the Pilgrimage. This is said to be built on the site where St Paul was buried there. As with all churches in Rome this is very beautiful, well worth the trip out to it, if you can go on an organised tour as they will give you much more information than you would get on your own.
LOVED IT!. A little farther from the center, but It's worth the trip, you can get easily by metro and you'll see how amazing it is.Big, beautiful building, great sculptures and paintings.

St Pauls. If you are not afraid of heights you must climb the staicase to the top of the dome. This in itself is an amazing feature to see how large the dome is and no central support. The staircase narrows near the top but when you finally reach the top you will find that you are at Rome's highest landmark.
Amazing!. Beautiful... you must go! Soo busy in the area but well worth ever second you spend amongst the crowds!

A must place to see if you are seeking the footsteps of St. Paul. This is an excellent example of the type of churces scattered all over Rome. This ediface is designated in honor and rememberence of St. Paul

A classic place to visit. If you go there in the fall, you have less of a crowd and can enjoy the unique architecture of the place. It's safe and clean and if you're into that sort of thing, a Sunday mass can be an experience.

Ditto. One of the 4 major Basilicas in Rome, fantastic architecture, the relics of St. Paul himself, the mosaics of all the Popes...what's not to love. A must on any trip to Rome. And they have a nice little gift shop. Unless you like cloister gardens and relics, I don't think the €4 for the cloister was worth it.

Definitely worth a visit. Yes, it is! we were quite surprised how little importance is given to this place compared to St.Peter's Basillica...Seems a bit unfair, as the place is no less grand or spectacular in terms of architecture, and inside decoration...plus! it gave me real goosebumps to stand in front of St.Paul's sarcofagus... It was far too overwhelming. The place is easy to find: just take Blue Metro line, stop of St.Paul's Basilica.
Well worth a visit. attraction is well worth seeing. We visited in December, which meant we didn't have to deal with the crowds
Rome's 4th Basilica. The original Basilica burned down so this one is not the original. It's a long way from all of Rome's other sights. I'd skip it.
MUST see. A religious experience even if you are a non-Christian
St Pauls. simply amazing. the architecture and history was great
WOW. The Basicila was so beautiful and ornate. Fun to see
One of the four major basilicas. Another major basilica among the only four of those to visit. Belief to be where St. Paul was buried.
Stand where thousands have and will. Loved the Basilica - not pleased that stalls have nodding head dolls of the Pope

LOVE this Basilica!. We visited St. Paul Outside the Walls last year but didn't have time on our most recent trip. I enjoyed the beautiful mosaics inside and out. The Basilica is beautiful and quiet. For me, it was worth the subway ride outside the walls to be able to spend some quiet time in this beautiful, soothing place.
St Paul - nice surprise. This is away from Rome Centro and historical centre, but very easy to get to. One of the 4 basilicas in Rome. I've visited this in 2 trips and just lovely - and no crowds !!

My favorite.... As a Christian, this was like Mecca (after JERUSALEM)
fo me to visit the tomb of this saint. The church itself was very big (it's one of the 4 main basilicas in Rome) and beautiful, even though it's a little farther away from the city center but it's still walking distance.

Majesty and space. A major basilica noted for representations of the heads of all the popes from St Peter to the present day. It should be equally noted for the fabulous apse mosaic. The nave is huge and appears even more so being kept free of chairs except for service time.The best way to get there is by Metropolitana Linea B to the stop named for the Basilica.
Beautiful!. We had a local tour guide that made this vist something to always remember.
Huge!. Massive building which beautiful inside and out. St Paul's tomb was beautiful

Must see but seldom visited. This gives you an excellent idea of what St Peters was like and maybe should have been left like; no crowds, great parks around; early tombs in the roofed area outside; great fish restaurant opposite
WOW!. Far more impressive than St Peters, no crowds, beautiful garden setting, fantastic mosaics.
Amazing!. So much bling gets rather samey! The Pope came out of his balcony on the Sunday. About 50,000 watching, but worth seeing.

Worth the Trip!. This beautiful basilica is a trek outside of Rome, but is worth the trip indeed. The gift shop sells amazing soaps, colognes, liquors, and chocolates made in the monastery here. Make sure to stop there!

Don't miss this gem. We spotted this from the other side of the road, had a closer look and were impressed by this lovely church. The next morning the bells didn't just ring, they played a tune- much nicer than the normal sirens and beeping from the traffic!
essential rome. this was exactly what i had expected you wont be dissappointed
A must-see in Rome. Download Rick Steve's audioguide podcast for a free tour

Worth the trek. Decided to visit based on reviews. I wasn't disappointed! Not many tourists (More on Wed. when the cruise ships come in). Gardens outside are lovely, and the Basilica is beautiful. Explore all the smaller chapels at the back. Paul's sarcophagus is visible behind glass as well as a section of chain, supposedly from his imprisonment. Can be reached by taxi or by bus.
Striking building with stunning outside walls. Loved the pictures of all the popes around the inside of the nave. St Paul's tomb is quite special too.

And go to the concerts...... Beautiful church. They have concerts there and the acoustics are incredible. We heard a violin recital and an opera recital in this beautiful place - all very special. Worth every euro.

Great Concert Series. Just returned from Rome and we happened to see a poster for a Mozart concert with a local group. 20 euro ticket was a bit steep but nonetheless was a great concert in a deligtfully acoustic building.

I love this church. I love this church because it is huge and historical. It is a vast building but not a wasteful one. It is in continual use and as a spectacle it is wonderfully impressive. It can be refreshingly cool on a very hot day. The art work in the ceiling is impressive and the connection with the Apostle Paul, to one who has been helped and inspired by his writings for some decades can be a moving experience. The sarcophagus of the Apostle is currently being examined by the R.C. church and they are possibly trying to tantalise us with their findings but to stand by the tomb and think that the Apostle Paul's remains are contained in the stone box beneath the alter is quite a thought.
Sheila C. Absolutely loved this place. Beautiful church, grounds and extremely good visitor facilities.

San Paolo Fuori Le Mura. Though a little out of the (tourist) way, definitely worth visiting! Probably better with a guide. A beautiful basilica. You can also get a blessing by touching the Holy Door. Also a nice souvenir shop and cafeteria right outside.

quick walk about. our hotel Residence Candia is a 20 minute walk to the Vatican. We just walked about taking photos and letting it sink in that we were there. We didn't have a lot of time so we were not able to go inside, but being outside was just lovely.

Amazing!. We were really looking forward to a visit here and were not disappointed. It's an amazing basilica! We actually went back a second time and were lucky enough to attend Mass there. Read up about it before you go as there is so much to see and if you know a bit about the place, it's a lot more interesting.

Ornate. I liked the design of the church. I enjoyed the history and the pictures of all the popes. I was disappointed that it was burned down, so in Rome terms it is like Epcot! It was rebuilt faithfully but is only about 150 years old. Epcot for Rome!

Amazing. Wear comfortable shoes, you have to walk slowly and make sure to take a lot of pictures, because you won't be able to remember everything, I am still looking at the pictures to really enjoy and appreciate all the history

Worth the effort. One of the major basilicas, it is, doubtless, a pilgrim's stop. You'll have to take the train for this one; just keep and eye on your camera or bag, especially as you approach the stations. It's beautiful. The garden just outside the doors is a place of special serenity and peace. If you don't have a guidebook for the the audio guide is worth the few euros--spend the money if you take the trouble to visit.

Breath-taking. This church is located just outside of central Rome but it's only a couple of metro stops past the Colosseum stop on the Red Line metro and totally worth the trip. It's about a 5 minute walk from the metro stop and it is a truly amazing and beautiful church. To start off, it's massive. Every square foot of it has such intricate detail and history. There isn't much else at that metro stop so you could see the church, spend about an hour or so exploring the inside, and then hop back on the metro and head back into town.One tip: the pizza place next to the McDonald's (across the street from San Paolo) is very good and reasonably priced.

One of the most underrated church in Rome. Many tourists flock to Vatican City and miss this place, hence there is very little crowds. Although its is quite far from city centre, the journey here is well worth it. This is a real architectural gem, one of the four Major Basilicas in Rome, and highly recommended

Just go. Take the metro. It's St. Paul!!!!!!!!!!!. The first time I went to Rome, we didn't go and from the momentwe planned to return, this was where I wanted to go. The fact that you are standing in front of the tomb of St. paul is awe inpsiring. I am Catholic, but any Christian who has read the New Testament, this is a pilgrimage to see the tomb of the apostle to the Gentiles. Here is what to do. We got on the Metro at the Piazza Republicca, there are ticket machines there. There are two lines, orange and blue. St. Paolo blue is the stop. You get your tickets, use a credit card it has all languages, then choose the all day pass, it was like 4 euros. At the Republicca, it is the orange line, don't be scared. Get on orange to termini and then you will have to switch to blue. Get on blue Laurentina is the final stop. It is like four stops and you can't miss the stop because that is the name. When you get off the train, head to the left and keep going, this station stinks to high heaven and it was gross, but keep your eyes on the prize. They have signs in the station with arrows pointing toward the basilica. You come up out of the Metro, and then turn right. You can almost see it as you emerge. Follow down about two blocks, and then you enter the church on the side door. Be sure you are dressed with covered shoulders, they will deny you access. St. Paul's tomb is smack dab in the center. There is a map as you enter. Be sure to go out the big doors at the far end, that is where the courtyard is with the statue they show on the websites. The side entrance is kind of....scruffy, but the front is spectacular. They also have super clean restrooms on the opposite side of where you will come in. Just so you know. Really, don't be scared of the metro. It is surreal and you will thank yourself for a lifetime for going. THEN, when you go home, read the book of Romans, it has a whole new perspective. God bless and safe journeys!

Most under-rated tourist attraction. It's amazing how location determines the popularity of a touristic attraction. Basilica di San Paolo is located just a few metro stations away from downtown, but for some reason a lot of tourists ignore that. The site of the basilica is absolutely amazing, it's quiet, well taken care of and possesses some really great sculptures. It's just as majestic, perhaps not as huge as Basilica di San Pietri, but it's worth visiting nonetheless. The entrance is free and you can take some really nice pictures. Again, it's very under-rated, because people usually don't visit it, so no matter what time of the day you get there, you'll find it almost empty, which, in my opinion is even better than being a part of a large crowd like in Saint-Peter's basilica.

St. Paul Outside the Walls - the hidden jewel. In my opinion this Basilica is definitely one of the top sights in Rome.Although the outside is somehow unsightly and common, the inside is spectacular. I was delighted with beautiful large mosaic, vast spaces and portraits of all popes since St. Peter. It is placed a little bit out of common tourist routes but there is a metro station nearby. There is no entrance fee and surrounding area is nice and quiet without too many people which I found very relaxing.We visited it at Wednesday afternoon around 17h and there was a Holy Mass in progress. Probably the place is more crowded in the morning and during weekends.I highly recommend it to everybody, especially those who do not like crowded sights with rivers of tourists swarming around.

Hidden gem. It is a bit out of the way but well worth the visit. It doesn't look that impressive from the outside, but the interior is amazing. We went on a Saturday afternoon and were amazed at how quite it was, probably only about 20 people in there. With no charge for entry, a definate thing to visit in Rome, true hidden gem.

Great interiors, outside nice gardens. The outside is a remake that iI do not like.The interiors are very nice, ande the huge mosaic is one of the most beautiful in Rome, and you can appreciate it fully because it is in a very ample space.

Off the path and outside the comfort zone. A beautiful church, a great story and a great name "Saint Paul's Outside the Wall's" (in italian "San Paolo fuori le Mura") was interesting and challenging. We had difficulty getting there - it's not really within the city - though we decided it was just off of the common tourist map and worth the hassle. After delaying several days we finally went to the Metro early in the morning with the aim that we would take the train to San Paolo and walk back to the city makings stops at Piramide and other locations along Via Ostiense.Arriving at the Termini station to take the B line 2. We went around is circles for a while figuring out where to buy tickets and finally picked up two tickets for 2 Euros at a tobacco shop (called Tabacchi in Italy, they sell bus and train tickets among other things). If we had waited we could have bought tickets at large ATM-like machines just prior to entering the turnstiles to the trains. Live and learn.Passing through the turnstiles we made our way to the platform. The platform was quite full and quickly got more and more full. We ride the T here in Boston from time to time and this was as busy as rush hour or say, after a Red Sox game. Romans are in our experience friendly, nice and quite helpful, so we were a little surprised by the pushing when we got on the second passing train. When we later discovered that one of my wife's purses was missing, we realized that this was when it happened. One young man in particular did not seem to want to let my wife pass and I had to physically pull her and push him to get her close to me. The purse he pocketed was the one carrying only ibuprofen, bismuth tablets, and some cotton swabs, the lucky guy. When we did finally make it to our stop we were rewarded with a brief but confusing search for San Paolo. There did not seem to be much signage, and the San Paolo stop on the Metro line is, how should I put this, in an intimidating state. We're not talking graffiti here, which I personally find to be non-threatening, we're talking about a lot of garbage in the street and a whole lot of vendor carts too close to the sidewalk. Which is all in a very real way an unfortunate state of affairs which would be easy to address. Saint Paul's is itself in an excellent state once you get inside. It's a beautiful church celebrating an important apostle. The whole site is well organized and well-documented with informative exhibits and excellent restoration. Perhaps some of the UNESCO funding and the local government effort can be directed to remedy some of these more easy to address concerns.

Rome and it's Glories. A must see is the Colleseum and to walk along the pathways of the Forum.....and to think about how many famous feet have traveled those paths before you. The mere fact that these structures are still standing for the benefit of all to experience makes it one of the most deserving sites to visit. You will be humbled by the very existence of these buildings, columns, plinths.....

A wonderful Surprise. St. Paul Outside the Walls was simply to be one of the stops on a bus tour of Rome. Yet, it became one of my favorite stops as we moved from the magnificent outside to the church itself and out to the cloister. For people of the Christian faith it is an emotionally moving holy site as the burial place of St. Paul. I highly recommend a visit.

Very serene and Tranquil. I really enjoyed my visit to San Paul Basilica. There were hardly any people here compared to the other places we visited and this is the first thing you notice. It was so nice and peaceful. It was nice to see the services going on, a priest taking confessions and we sat on the pews and looked at it with awe. The ceiling was very beautiful. The entire building is grand. I much prefered this to San Pietro Basilica becuase of how peaceful it was. Personally I think this place is underrated which made it a bonus for us no hoardes or tour groups insight!

A quiet place. I visited this place in the month of July and it was not as crowded as the other places. I thought it was rather peaceful compared to the rest of Rome during tourist season. The alabaster windows are amazing! I could've stared at all day.
